After first few levels you have seen everything this game has to offer. Nothing really changes, the stages just get longer and more frustrating. The gameplay boils down to trial and error. Even one misstep will make reaching the goal impossible and you have to keep starting over until you memorize the path perfectly. Sometimes a failure isn't even your fault as enemies can break the path too, even if you tried to keep them at bay with the otherwise completely useless bird. (Local co-op, yeah right.)If this were just a calm, slow-paced puzzle game, I could have lived with that. But no, there are "timed" puzzles as well and they really irk my nerves. For example, there was this one stage in which you have to keep a snowball rolling so it will eventually reach a button which opens the gate to the exit. You have to keep opening gates and eliminating enemies from its path, but over half of the time you can't even see, where the snowball is going, no matter how you try to turn the camera. So besides learning the right path, you have to have almost pixel-perfect timing too.Utterly boring game with unlikable characters and a story that nobody cares for. I paid about 1â‚¬ for this and still I think I got ripped off. Not recommended for anyone.

I'm not sure whether to call this a puzzle game or not. All you have to do is to get to the goal, hitting switches, dodging environmental hazards and the occasional "enemy". Once you found the correct path to take, you can finish a level without much trouble. Collecting coins is optional but to unlock more levels you'll need a certain amount.Dont bother with the DLC since all it does is add 3 additional levels which arent too interesting nor challenging and you'll be done with those in no time.I guess this is a good choice when you feel the need to take a break from other games that piss you off.On a side note: Whenever I start this game and the splash screen "Plays best on Alienware" shows up I just cant help myself and I have to laugh.

This is a rather long review, so if you want a quick summary of why I recommend this title just skip to the Results section and read from there.Fatshark created a fantastic little puzzle game which puts you to the test. Hamiltonâ€™s Great Adventure pushes out levels that pose mysteries and threats around every turn. Story:Hamiltonâ€™s Great Adventure starts you off telling the stories of your great exploits to your granddaughter. You relive Hamiltonâ€™s glory days as you try to get the parts for a machine required for a purpose you will learn if you beat the campaign. You and your bird, Sasha, must complete puzzles from Brazil, Egypt, India, and the Secret Islands. As the game progress Hamilton gets further into his tale and new characters are introduced. The game includes hilarious dialogue, with an interesting story that keeps you guessing, and levels that keep posing new challenges. As you progress through the game you obtain answers to the mystery and you learn all about how the story began. Gameplay:Hamilton's Great Adventure is a puzzle solving game which knowing the answer is the key. Unlike some puzzle solving games where you can see the solution but be unable to complete the challenge because of a simple annoyance in clicking a button at exactly the right time. This game puts your mind to the test to solve puzzles by completing challenges by using the correct answer. Itâ€™s fun and rather simple, yet some puzzles are a little more difficult than others. The games graphics are not the best, but they are crisp and the story is pleasant. Sasha can be difficult to control and managing two characters is rather difficult if you are not on your toes. Menus:One of my major gripes is that the in game menu is annoying to navigate. They tried to make the menu look like a book, but this is not very useful as you don't actually know what information is on what page. Ultimately you may have to flip through the whole book if you are looking for a simple answer. Hints:The pink vials are used to power up Hamiltonâ€™s special abilities. You can play as Sasha at the start of the level before activating the timer, so if you want to you can gather lots of the pink vials before even technically starting a level. You can also scare off the flying blowfish that attack Sasha by using a taunt when they are about to hit Sasha (it causes them to blow up and float away).Result:Hamilton's Great Adventure doesn't pull you in keeping you on your toes from level to level. yet, the game offers fun puzzles which you can solve during your spare time. I would like it if they had checkpoints. I don't play too many puzzle game so maybe they all don't have any checkpoints during levels. If you like to solve puzzles and you're tired of traditional puzzle solving games that challenge a user based on luck or precise click timing then this is for you. Pros:+Simple gameplay without too many commands to learn+Smooth movements+Fun and rather complex puzzles+Fantastic difficulty curve, the puzzles get gradually more difficult rather than exponentially+Nice art style which makes the games simple graphics seem rather elegantCons:-Very difficult menu navigation-Not a very riveting story (though itâ€™s a puzzle game so you're here for the puzzles not for the tale)-Can be infuriating when you have solved the first part of the puzzle, but have to keep resolving to get to the second part of the puzzle

Ugh, so glad I only paid one dollar for this game.  The idea is decent, but the controls and camera really bog it down. Also, all the game mechances revolving around the bird are just annoying and pointless. The game would be significantly better without it.

AVOID - DOES NOT WORK IN WINDOWS 10  an if forum posts are to be believed DOES NOT RUN ON AMD chips. Game crashes as soon as launched. Not help in forums worked.Picked up as part of the FatShark sale bundle so unable to refund. Should not be allowed to sell games that do not work.
Does NOT work on Windows 10. Under any circumstance.I was able to leave the game on the crash popup for an hour to get my card drops, so it's got that going for it.

Information / Review English Hamilton's Great Adventure is a puzzle / adventure game developed by Fatshark. Gameplay / Story The intrepid adventurer Ernest Hamilton and his ingenious bird Sasha are on the trail of the ancient mystery of the lost continent and take the player on a fantastic journey around the world! In four different game environments you have to outsmart lurking enemies, overcome tricky obstacles and collect as many treasures as possible in order to secure a place on the leaderboard. But only players with excellent problem-solving skills with ingenious timing can achieve the goal. Pro + captivating principle+ crazy opponents+ funny sound effects+ relaxed / mystical music+ idyllic adventure backdrops+ many optional treasures+ Achievements and trading cards Contra - dry drawings as cutscenes- dull and boring story- short playing time Conclusion Hamilton's Great Adventure is an old-school puzzle platformer that's a bit like Indiana Jones. Information / Review Deutsch Hamilton's Great Adventure ist ein Puzzle/Abenteuer Spiel, welches von Fatshark entwickelt wurde.  Gameplay / Geschichte Der unerschrockene Abenteurer Ernest Hamilton und sein genialer Vogel Sasha sind dem uralten RÃ¤tsel um den verschwundenen Kontinent auf der Spur und nehmen den Spieler mit auf eine fantastische Reise um die Welt! In vier verschiedenen Spielumgebungen gilt es, lauernde Feinde zu Ã¼berlisten, knifflige Hindernisse zu Ã¼berwinden und so viele SchÃ¤tze wie mÃ¶glich einzusammeln, um sich einen Platz in der Bestenliste zu sichern. Aber nur Spieler mit hervorragenden ProblemlÃ¶sungsfÃ¤higkeiten mit einem genialen Timing kÃ¶nnen das Ziel erreichen. Pro + fesselndes Prinzip+ verrÃ¼ckte Gegner+ witzige Soundeffekte+ entspannte/mystische Musik+ idyllische Abenteuer-Kulissen+ viele optionale SchÃ¤tze+ Multiplayer+ Errungenschaften und Sammelkarten Kontra - trockene Zeichnungen als Zwischensequenzen- Ã¶de und langweilige Geschichte- kurze Spielzeit Fazit  Hamilton's Great Adventure bietet dir ein Puzzle-Plattformer von alter Schule und erinnert ein wenig an Indiana Jones.

Hamilton's Great Adventure is a great balanced adv/puzzler. You run around with Hamilton, and the bird Sasha helps out with collecting special abilities, reaching levers and acts as a decoy. The quests gets trickier and trickier. I have only played the first world yet, but I am having a lot of fun
Crashes frequently on Steam Deck and on desktop. Would not recommend

I am not sure I understand why the storefront says the game only works on Windows Vista or Windows 7, or why there are reviews from people complaining the game does not work. The game does work. I got it from a Humble Bundle and have been pleasantly surprised. I've tried the game on a laptop (Windows 10) with an Intel processor, and then on my desktop (Windows 11) with an AMD processor and Nvidia graphics. In both cases, it works.

Absolute masterpiece, one of the most beautiful games I've played in my life.You NEED to play this game, I've never seen so much love and care put into a game.It would've been a 10/10 game, even if they put HALF as much effort into this, but they really went that extra mile and created this insanely beautiful masterpiece.BUY THIS.

So, I'd bought this game a long time ago. It took me awhile because I knew it was a walking simulator, and I'd been burned on those before. When I read about this game though, I thought, "maybe this will be a good one, then." Eventually I bought it on a sale, but never played it. Always wanted to, but never did.I think the reason why was that... it had been built up so much that if I played it, I wouldn't want to reach the end, because something special would end... that I'd have to leave a special place.And ya know, I was right.This game (well, walking simulator) affected me in a way few games have. It really is a special game... it has a melencholy story that I related to quite a bit. The imagination is nearly unmatched in the gaming space. (And I've been gaming since 1981.) It has great voice acting, and well.... I suppose I could go on, but who knows if anyone will see this buried under all the other reviews.I highly recommend this game. It's one of the highest "recommends" I felt I've ever made. You really owe it to yourself to play this. Once you do you'll understand why.11/10

I am 50 years old and I have been playing videos games since the 80s. I have played "What remains of Edith Finch" through twice, once when it came out (2017) and then again years later (2024). It's as if it did not age. It's like a great movie that you watch again and again. This game is a true masterpiece. Despite it's short length, the story and the emotions it leaves with you with stays with you for years. This is one of the best story driven games I have ever played and I have played A LOT. Also the way the story is told and the interface is really innovative and creative 10/10. I will be back in another few years to play it again.

Do yourself a favor if you get eye-strain or nauseated from the forced motion blur and/or the chromatic aberration and go to %appdata%/Local/FinchGame/Saved/Config/WindowsNoEditor and open the "Engine.ini" file and copy in the following:[/script/engine.renderersettings]r.SceneColorFringe.Max=0r.DefaultFeature.MotionBlur=0This will disable both effects which in my case completely removed any strain I was having.

It's hard to find words to describe this game. It's gobsmacking. There are very few games that make me stop just to put a hand to my mouth and ssay "Oh my God". But this is one of them. The story was incredible, and I found myself playing it all in one sitting. It's quite short, but don't let that put you off. It's the perfect length for what it is, any longer, it would have dragged on, any shorter, it would have seem rushed. It's perfect, and I have nothing negative to say. Just play it.
It takes 2 hours to play and a lifetime to reflect.
I think theres a Lewis Finch in all of us.
one of those games you wish you could play for the first time again.

My buddy and I were talking a year ago or so about how videos games have, we think, ultimately greater potential for storytelling than film.The big argument for reading books, for instance, versus watching movies besides the fact, obviously, that books have more overall content since movies have to cut things down for time is that reading is an active process.You're the one scanning from one word to the next word and making sense of it.It's up to you to keep the story going.You invest more in it, and it becomes more precious to you because of that.While watching a movie is a passive act: you hit Play and you just sit there.It comes at you regardless of your level of engagement and doesn't require anything from you for the story to unfold.This is, of course, not to say that movies are bad. We've all been terrified, moved to tears, and broken down laughing from them but when you consider the pros and cons of both mediums, you realize video games bring both sets of those pros together.Playing a video game is an active process.You could easily argue even more so than reading.You more or less control what happens when and how.And even if a plot in a video game takes one linear path, the fact that you're the one pushing it forward tends to make it far more compelling and immersive.That being said - If you haven't played What Remains of Edith Finch,I highly recommend it if you're into narrative-driven indie games.On a very basic level, it's about a supposedly cursed family called the Finches.you play as Edith Finch, the last living member as she walks around the old, bulbous family estate looking for clues as to how each family member passed away.When you enter each family member's room, you find out how they died and experience their final moments in a flashback.So it's a pretty dark game. One of the flashbacks is straight-up a baby drowning in a bathtub and yes, you play as the baby.And another one is about a guy who's lived with agoraphobia his whole life and one day he finally gets the courage to go outside and is immediately hit by a train.So, some are straight forward, others are shrouded in fantasy and have to be inferred.EDIT 05/05/23:''Pain travels through families until someone is ready to feel it, for many of us our generational curse is avoidance. We come from people who just act like it didn't happen. But pain demands to be felt, and somewhere along the line - a child will be born whose charge is to feel it all. These are your shamans, your priests & priestesses, your healers... You call them mental health patients and label their power as depression, anxiety, bipolar disorder and the like. But these are the ones who are born with the gift of feeling, and as we all know:You can't heal the pain that you refuse to feel.'' -  Stephi Wagner, Healing the Mother Wound, - Dionne Shannette Wood

â€œIt is astonishing just how much of what we are can be tied to the beds we wake up in in the morning, and it is astonishing how fragile that can be.â€ â€• Neil Gaiman, CoralineForewordIf you're looking for a more traditional review, skip to 'Conclusion'.First, a real storyWhen I was 7, I found out that two brothers killed each other inside my house for the money my father paid for it. It turns out that all those years before my father renovated the house, two families lived crammed in it, in the same space that now snugly holds three people, one dog and one turtle â€“ and an unholy amount of books, but that's a story for another time. I still don't understand how they coexisted there together, all I know is that they didn't do so peacefully.When I was 10, I found out that, before I was even born, one of my cousins had a panic attack when he entered the guestroom, where he was supposed to sleep in for the night while his mother â€“ my mother's sister â€“ was out for two days. He never slept there again.When I was 14, one of my then closest friends walked into my bedroom for the first time, turned to me and asked casually "you know you don't live alone in here, right?" I'm not sure how much I believe in all this. I've always been kind of a skeptic. But the thing is: my skepticism works just fine, as soon as I walk out the door. Before then, it's whack.My watershed moment in understand all this was the year I got a ride home from a couple that owned a stationary store by my old school. Turns out they lived in the same neighborhood as I did â€“ which was not typical. We chatted all the way to my house, where the driver, a man of some 50 or so years and a cheery attitude, grew eerily silent. "My friend Arthur used to live here." He paused. I was a kid back then, but even then I could tell he was choosing his next words very carefully. He finished with "before he died." That was the first time I learned his name. I had all kinds of questions, but I knew that that was not the time for them. Nowadays, I wish I had asked more.ConclusionEven though my house is not as big as Edith's and has no bricked-up doors like Coraline's, the weird shape of the wooden floorboards and the questions I still have about feeling unwell in my parent's bedroom hold just as many secrets. What Remains of Edith Finch reminded me of all that history through some of the most curious use of level design in story telling I have ever witnessed, an Andersonian way of presenting its host of characters and an unspeakably fantastic timing with all its singular and unexpected deliveries â€“ all that to the tune of my all-time favorite Tchaikovsky piece.What Remains of Edith Finch went over and beyond both what I expect to get out of it and the praise I heard about it, with the added bonus of tying so well to my own personal history.Regardless of how much of yourself you find in Edith's tale, if you have a thirst for masterfully packed words and a hunger to see a brilliant story unfold before your very eyes, dive in. What Remains of Edith Finch plays like that delicious book you couldn't put down during that summer all those years ago, and leaves you with that familiar bittersweet happiness of having both finished it and being harshly awoken to the real world once again.I strongly recommend this game to story lovers, wannabe game designers, aspiring writers and, above of all, all those who have insatiable curiosity for those things we've all been told are better left buried.â€œBut how can you walk away from something and still come back to it?â€ â€• Neil Gaiman, Coraline

The core design idea of Gorogoa is so incredibly strong and well-executed that the rest doesn't really matter all that much. You get a square screen broken into four sections, each of which features an image that you often can zoom in to, out of, move, or break into layers. Your goal is to guide the main character across multiple scenes (lives?) by changing perspective and fitting different images together. That's it.And it's absolutely brilliant.The game is elevated above being a simple clever puzzle by wrapping its beautiful mechanics into a Buddhist (Induist?) narrative, showing the character across multiple lives and emphasizing that the world itself is structured like a fractal, with something as insignificant and mundane as a lamp or an apple hiding a whole new universe inside. The idea, while nothing new, sings perfectly in tune with the gameplay.Gorogoa is indeed short, which I think is a plus, since the puzzles never get overly complex so as to become frustrating.The art style and music could have, perhaps, been more unique, but even as it is, Gorogoa is definitely a must play for any puzzle lover and anyone who enjoys tight experiences dedicated to doing one thing right.

This game is art. It doesn't take much of your time completing it but the hour you put in playing this game is worth more than a ton of other kind of investments in your life. Clear your calendar and sit in front your computer and click this game open. Sit back and enjoy the purity and creativity the developer has made for your soul.Edited/Added on:Perhaps to address the technical aspects more: The puzzle mechanics in this game are unique. That, in my opinion, makes up a lot to its rather short playhour. If you don't tend to judge a game's quality solely based on its duration, then this game is worth your time and money.

Gorogoa is a surreal experience in a world filled with optical illusions and Escher-esque constructions SynopsisSeven years in the making, Gorogoa is a lavishly illustrated puzzle game that plays with logic and perception, encourages lateral thinking and tests the boundaries of its own self-imposed interactions.+ProsLavishly illustrated with excellent animationsMinimalist playstyle that pushes the boundaries of the formSeamlessly blends its symbolism into the mechanics-ConsLinearity of progression with little replayabilityPuzzles have only a single set solutionLack of options to set graphics  GameplayGorogoa has a simple premise. Four panels, and a single starting image. This image may be manipulated to split it into multiple panels that slowly unfolds an incredibly complex world. At first glance Gorogoa is 2-dimensional. Images fit together along the sides and searching for similarities to create connections is often done on the peripheral edges of the playing area. Yet it also manages to overcome this limitation by creating an illusion of depth. Some panels form borders through which one can peer into distant spaces, zooming in and through panels to find new layers of the world to interact with. Light sources in one world shine through into the others illuminating new spacesâ€¦ and new possibilities. In Gorogoa everything is interconnected. https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=1507998278And this is at the heart of Gorogoaâ€™s design philosophy. Searching to see how things fit, finding clues and similarities in its own internal symbolism to assist you in solving the puzzles that confront you. And then applying it all to the games mechanics, whether it lies in the slow inevitability of gravity or the intricate connections of disparate pages. Everything is logicalâ€¦ but it requires you to â€œthink-outside-the-boxâ€ and thereâ€™s a deep investment into lateral thinking required to successfully solve Gorogoaâ€™s mysteries.The game is somewhat cyclical in nature, and some motifs do become repetitive, such as the ability to discover sources of light. The game does reflect on this repetition of puzzles in some pointsâ€¦ such as when the young boy struggles up a mountain staircase in a Sisyphean task until you finally resolve the puzzle. Itâ€™s these moments of reflection in the game itself where it shows a partial self awareness, that makes it deeply representative of the human condition.And Gorogoa does have an anthropocentric viewpoint. The laws of Gorogoaâ€™s world do not determine your ability to interact, but rather its your mastery of their mechanics that allows you to progress. This makes the laws of the world subservient to the players agency. When this sense of control is combined with the manipulation of the universal symbols and the eureka moments of successfully solving a puzzle it creates an intense feeling of power and mastery that is self-gratifying, and encourages the further pursuit of enigmas to solve.It is light on playtime which may be a concern for some, but the careful integration of Steam achievements do offer some replayability and larger scale problem solving. Especially achievements that offer economical tile movement (a puzzle in itself) as well as speed runs and solving certain puzzles on the first trial. The game does also provide hints, by pinging interactive areas of the tiles, so you should never be stuck for too long.  GraphicsThe art draws from various styles and influences, neoclassicism is an obvious one in the statuesque figures that portray frozen moments. Art Deco surfaces in the detailed furniture designs that draw onesâ€™ gaze across their textured surfaces as well as in aspects of cultural art: from mandalas to runic shapes that pepper the portraits at various intervals. Itâ€™s in its art that Gorogoa crafts its rich metaphorical world. https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=1507948276Each panel further assists these meanings: ranging from a tranquil city balcony, to Himalayan vistas, and shattered city scapes, the remnants of some unknown disaster. Gorogoaâ€™s art is universal both in thematic choices and in what it actually depicts, creating a world that is believable and exotic at the same time.The game does offer automatic widescreen support, but doesnâ€™t allow you to set the resolution yourself, and the only option you will be able to adjust is whether the game is windowed or not.  NarrativeGorogoa doesnâ€™t have a narrative in the traditional sense, but that is not to say it has no story. Rather the ambiguity of the world renders it capable of allowing players to inform their own stories, each unique and relevant to the individual. It does this through the symbolism of the game, partially creating internal meaning (to assist in puzzles solutions) but also by drawing on larger cultural meanings. https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=1507947818The world is populated by dreamers, contemplating their desks hunched over books, searching for their own meaningsâ€¦ their thoughts and dreams assisting you in your own search for meaning. A partially visible dragon emerges from the city, perhaps an agent of prosperity or a deeply seated echo of a Jungian subconscious. Interactions between individuals are disconnected yet when viewed from the abstract position of the player harmonise in unexpected ways. The unpersonified boy, representative of the everyman and projection to show the players progression searches throughout the environment and is ultimately rewarded by five objectsâ€¦ though what their purpose is, their value, or even what they are, is up to your own interpretation. ConclusionGorogoa presents itself with elegance and depth. Itâ€™s welcoming to both those who want a satisfying puzzle game and those who like some philosophy thrown into the dynamics of play without being too erudite. It's lightweight on playtime but thoroughly worth experiencing. If you want something truly unique and different to play Gorogoa should be highest on your list.Score: 9/10 ~Superb~This review is curated by Alexander's Club Curations and Virtual Visions

Gorogoa, interesting name, even more interesting game.  A buddy of mine at work who is a fellow programmer came over to me and said I have to check out â€œGorogoaâ€.  At the time I had no clue what it was and didnâ€™t even know how to spell it.  We had talked extensively about Zachtronic games and games that are like programming as well as Cookie Clicker, so I was confused.  Later that day I walked by and I saw him playing it.  He was moving tiles around a whiteboard and the tiles were gorgeous, but the thing that enraptured me was how the tiles were able to connect.  I went back to my desk and picked up the bundle on Steam with Edith Finch as I was looking forward to playing both games. I was not disappointed in the least with either purchase. Gorogoa is an odd game, but the biggest thing to know about it is itâ€™s absolutely one of the best looking games Iâ€™ve ever seen.  Itâ€™s not big, or stylistic, itâ€™s just a gorgeous game filled with beautiful art.  The game travels through a number of locations, but since everything is based on a tile itâ€™s all simple two-dimensional representations of scenes.  The way the tiles connect and interlace is a thing of beauty. You can go from a beautiful tree to the inside of someoneâ€™s room, and back in a few clicks and each tile and transition is gorgeous.  There are a few pieces at the end that really stand out, but thereâ€™s really never a weak image to stare at. The gameplay is hard to explain but the idea is that the player is able to take tiles and position them, sometimes connecting them, sometimes overlapping them, and sometimes pulling them apart to change the images.  Through the entire game, thereâ€™s a character on a quest to get five objects.  The story follows him but the player usually has to leave him behind to solve some puzzle allowing the character to move forward.   Examples of this can be as simple as getting an apple to fall out of a tree for the character by connecting the branches of the tree and letting a crow fly away, or to light up a lamp by layering the lamp tile over a star tile. Itâ€™s rather brilliant the way the game plays with the art and the art is manipulated so simply by the player.  There are complex puzzles here and a few tricks, but the gameplay here is in service to the art and the story, rather than being the core reason for someone to play the game. Thatâ€™s not to say this lacks gameplay, but the gameplay is a way to reach the next art piece and then you have a chance to explore it. The story though is unique.  Itâ€™s a wordless tale of a dragon that terrorizes a city, and a person who has to go get five objects. Without words, itâ€™s hard to really understand or explain the story without someone experiencing it and honestly after playing through it, Iâ€™m not one hundred percent sure what I saw.  Itâ€™s not obscure though, which is something I like.  I donâ€™t feel like the story is hidden or you have to make large leaps of logic.  Itâ€™s just not clear exactly what the story is. Yet the characterâ€™s goal is almost always clear.  The locations and actions are wonderful and Iâ€™m sure people will claim to â€œunderstandâ€ it, but I think itâ€™s more an experience based game, than a direct narrative.  The meaning of each part of the story is available to interpretation by the player, and the final story is one the player can develop through multiple playthroughs. There are a few issues here.  As great as the graphics are, the game has a few issues that itâ€™s not immediately clear when the screen is layered.  The player can sometimes remove a window frame from the screen, or pull an object out of a screen.  Nine out of ten times this is a bit obvious, but there are at least one or two times that is hard to really notice and can be missed. The game is also a bit straightforward, there are only a couple red herrings, and Iâ€™m not even sure thereâ€™s a true red herring in the game as I believe everything youâ€™re allowed to do in the game is required at some point. As an achievement fan, Iâ€™m a little annoyed at two of them.  There is a 30-minute run which is very tight, and a 500-move one that isnâ€™t displayed in the game, so Iâ€™m not sure if the game wasnâ€™t counting my run for both of them, or if I went over and by how much.  Just a touch annoying when attempting (and failing) a speedrun playthrough. The final issue is going to be the biggest problem, this game is short.  I believe I beat it in 90 minutes, I replayed the game, and as mentioned there is a goal to get under 30 minutes.  90 minutes is hard to spin for the length of the game.  At 15 bucks, thatâ€™s a dollar every 6 minutes.  Youâ€™re purchasing this game more based on the art than anything and that is a steep price.  Itâ€™s odd because that should make me rage against this game, but I think the game is worth it, especially if you pick up the bundle that gives you a (small) discount on both games. I feel forced to give this game a recommendation because I love the experience and the gameplay.  The art is beautiful, the story, as hard as it is to nab, is beautiful, and I believe I played through it three times now.  Itâ€™s not going to win the best value but it still will entrap and engross almost any player.   I enjoyed it, and thatâ€™s what Iâ€™m going for, even if itâ€™s a little more than I wanted to spend, I felt enriched by the end of it.  Iâ€™m forced to recommend everyone else at least consider giving it a try. If you enjoyed this review or want to see what other games I enjoyed you can find my curator page at this link. http://store.steampowered.com/curator/31803828-Kinglink-Reviews/ Give me a follow.

Not particularly challenging, but it has its fair share of epiphany moments. Aesthetically it's beautiful, my only gripe is, indeed, that it's too short, but I'd rather be left wanting more than get bored.

A really good game with interesting mechanics. Worlds within other worlds. It's not easy to describe but it's definitely stimulating for the mind. Gorogoa is a rather peculiar puzzler that tasks you with placing up to four living storybook tiles into their proper positions on a two-by-two grid. this causes the story to unfold, ultimately allowing a young boy to collect various fruits in a bowl as he travels forth under the watchful eye of a strange beast.The complicating factor is that each tile may contain an interactive, hand-drawn scene with several screens and animations, meaning youâ€™ll need to pan, zoom in and out, click on hotspots that look important, then drag the tiles aroundâ€”even layering them onto or removing them from one anotherâ€”until theyâ€™re oriented in a manner which permits the boy to proceed in the overall environment.Little else like Gorogoa exists and the art and animations are exquisite. tile interactions are clever, especially when theyâ€™re creating brand new scenes out of thin air, but not so cleverly designed that occasional experimentation isnâ€™t necessary. the silent story is surreal but not particularly engaging. and the soundtrack is just adequate and in the background. There isn't much thatâ€™s helpful to say about Gorogoa for those on the fence. Watching a minute or two of gameplay is likely the best tool to know with a fair degree of certainty whether itâ€™s a game youâ€™d enjoy. reviews arenâ€™t particularly helpful for determining that, in this instance.

â€œIf you realize that all things change, there is nothing you will try to hold on to.â€â€• Lao Tzu, Tao Te ChingIn one word, Gorogoa is â€œiridescentâ€.ForewordGorogoa is the first and only game Iâ€™ve bought on release day. General ImpressionsI still recall my awe back in 2012, playing the Gorogoa demo utterly mesmerized by the sagacity of moving bits and pieces of a painting into a brand new whole of an even prettier composition. The awe of playing the finished piece expressed itself tenfold on my face as I clicked, dragged, combined and sometimes simply stopped to admire the smooth animated scene that unfolded itself before my eyes.Sadly, I lack the words and the eloquence to cover the feeling of finally playing a long-awaited game and the joy of it surpassing sky-high expectations -- so I'll refrain from attempting.ConclusionGorogoa is a puzzle game of wonderment and out-of-the-box thinking that expresses itself in the most delightful way. Jason Roberts brings forth a labor of love that deserves its very own category due to its signature presentation and quirky level designs. Like an opal, its iridescence stuns even when still, but as you swiftly twist and turn it under the shimmering sunlight, it glows with colors and undertones you never would have thought were there.This is a game to be appreciated in one sitting, by those willing to succumb to contemplation and to the pleasure of unfolding each scene with the curiosity and unexpectedness of a childâ€™s mind.

If you're in need of a deep healing for your soul, but not in the mood to meditate for 100 hours, books are boring for you, and it is cold and unpleasant to go for a nature walk, and all your friends are busy with Christmas (or any other activities and you're not among them) - Gorogoa might just be that little artsy cup of tea. I'm not sure whether I was mesmerized by unique puzzles, or simply puzzled by mesmerizing and mysterious experience, but I am iron confident in one thing: I have enjoyed my time and felt  child-like  engagement, while playing with parts and frames, and going through beautifully hand-crafted story till the very end in my first try! Game had me at hello.  The story might be a bit confusing, but don't worry - attention to details and little things is what captures one mind and the idea behind this indie title's mechanics is simple, but not really. It's hard to explain, but basically what you observe is not the full picture and there's always more if you're willing to seek. Difficulty level? You don't have to be a puzzle guru, however it's not a walk in park either. Just pay your mind to details and be patient. It's all about the journey and staying in the sweet present moment, and eventually you'll be rewarded for it. There's not much after completion, the story is always the same - unless you would like to go for a speed run (yes, it's there. Y tho?) or some particular achievements to unlock (there're couple of them you most likely won't be able to get on your first try), but the entire experience is well worth it. Music adds to general vibes and a big part of the illustrative-comic-book style narrative. Even if this charming little piece of art may not appear as your perfect game, it sure is will offer you a soulful, captivating adventure and will take your thoughts away for a couple of hours. At the end of the day it might be exactly what you're looking for.Thank you for reading, lots of love ~

Sometimes simplicity is all you need, no words, no fancy graphics, just beautiful art to deliver a powerful messageFlorence is a very short interactive story of a girl and some stages of her life. It's simple, lasts only for about and hour but has a huge impact on you.The idea along with the artstyle is really neat. The whole gameplay is just scrolling through images sometimes doing simple tasks. But those tasks usually have a deeper meaning. There are some moving scenes, again with a meaning.It's a very heartwarming and maybe a little heartbreaking story but so is life. A lot of people will see themselves in this game, same stuff many people go through in their life.Sometimes you need a little push to go on. You make memories, you reminisce about the past, think about how life has changed and how you changed. Falling in love, getting to know that person which at first might seem difficult. Big hurtful words you say without thinking. All the hardships and joyful moments of your life.  But you need to remember even if everything falls down you can start painting your world with colors again. It's all there, represented through simple yet beautiful art. Puzzles (this part completely got me), coloring, walking, it's beautiful. I don't know what it is, but this game has something which triggers emotions and makes you think, maybe go to your partner and hug him/her, tell your mother you love her.Graphically it's very minimalistic but beautifully drawn. Not a lot to talk about graphics.No ultrawide for obvious reasons. Performance? No need to talk about it, if your PC can show pictures it will run this game.Music is really nice and it reflects the emotions your going through but I wish there would be a better transition when music changes.Get this if you appreciate art and interactive stories. The game is great but it's very short, sure it's only 5â‚¬ but i'd still suggest waiting for a sale. But hey at least it's not 20â‚¬ like Gone Home (loved it too btw, but the price...).ProsBeautiful artGood musicYour life on a plateConsCould be a little longerFollow my curator page for more
If you do not let go, you cannot complete the game.

Too much for too little? The game hovers over/under an hour (depending on your pace) and there really isn't much in terms of replayability....besides going through it again or trying to obtain all the achievements (which aren't challenging), this at most would add a couple more hours.So in short you don't get much content for the price tag, with that said what you do get is quality.... a lot of it, ranging from the art to the music and everything in between. Now with that in mind, I believe that if the lack of content hinders you too much wait for a sale, but if not go ahead and pick it up you probably won't regret it.  What's inside? Story is very straightforward without much depth behind it, but that's not necessarly a bad thing... at least when it comes to this game. What makes an otherwise simple plot into something much more enticing is how everything like the art style, music, flow from one scene to the next and especially the interactions complement one another in order to create a sense of immersion w/everything that comes with that feeling.  Conclusion I highly recommend this game for anyone with feeeels and without. It's short, but as they say it "packs a punch".
Whoever's reading this, I hope you find your happiness.

Started strong, ended annoyingly.Moral of the story? People don't matter, relationships don't matter, just do what you want and never compromise because that thing you haven't done since you were a kid is totally going to work out as a new career.It paints a rather unhealthy picture of relationships - that "routine" is somehow negative - stagnant- rather than safe and stable and a foundation to grow something new on. That arguments should be allowed to blow up relationships, and are not simply things that you need to work on as a couple.I liked the art, liked the music, liked the plot until the final 3 or 4 chapters. But it all fell apart and tries to teach a very vapid moral that someone in their early 20's who has never had a meaningful relationship would idealize.At least it was short.

Before I get into this, this game is really something special and you should definitely give it a shot.   At the time of writing this review, I have completed two journeys. My first journey began with me meeting another player at the first stage. Their scarf was longer than mine so I assumed that they'd know their way around the block and continued following them pretty closely. We flew through the first couple stages as they helped me find some hidden Glyphs and we had fun chirping at each other, I was beginning to get attached. As we progressed through the game we were met with challenges, we both nearly met our ends on a couple occasions and the thrills and suspense I felt while worrying for the safety of this complete and total stranger on the internet was like nothing any game had ever made me feel before. Eventually, we managed to persevere and reached our goal, walking into the light side-by-side as our Journey came to a close. It was an amazing experience. But the gravity of it all didn't really kick in until my second Journey.I jumped right back in as soon as my first Journey came to a close. But this time, there was no one waiting for me at the first stage. I took my time, not having a partner to worry about, explored more and collected some Glyphs I had missed. I remembered everything my friend from my first Journey had taught me, and made quick work of the challenges that had seemed so daunting just an hour or so ago. It wasn't until I was at the end again, standing atop a cliff side with the end of the game before me, that the gravity of it all set in. I turned around, looking behind me to wait for my friend to catch up when I remembered... I was alone this time. Staring out over the beautiful landscape, I remembered soaring through the cloth updrafts of the final stage with my friend and finally realized just how meaningful that first Journey was. It was never about the destination, nor was it even about the Journey, it was about the friend I had made along the way. I'll never forget you, Isal my beloved.
whoever just made hearts in the snow with me i will never forget you

Have you ever met somebody, a complete stranger, and over the course of a confined amount of time found yourself opening up to them?Maybe you were waiting for a bus, perhaps you were traveling via train or plane.  Perhaps it started over a comment about their shirt, perhaps they liked your hair or maybe you simply bumped into a each other and for a few hours, maybe even a few days, you found a friend in a place you weren't looking for one to begin with.You spoke to them about your family.  About life and loves, shared laughter and maybe a meal--for whatever reason you both simply understood that within this moment you were both safe.  You had a friend, a bit of warmth in what should've been a solitary expedition and not a single moment passed that you weren't grateful for it.Hours passed, perhaps less or perhaps more...maybe even days?  Maybe you traded numbers or perhaps you couldn't? Separated in a crowd, splitting for a different terminal--maybe you both were even just afraid to spoil the moment?  Either way, time and circumstance just as easily as it brought you two together saw fit that you two must be apart once more.Do you remember their name? Their face? Even if you don't I'll bet you can remember the moments--you remember the warmth and the glow. the jokes, the philosophical debates and the commentary.  The sound of their chuckle is like a distant song to you, their smile a fading photograph in the depths of your mind.The older you get, the more time passes, the more all of that seems to have been a dream.  Fleeting, a soft ache knowing that it can never be repeated but...it never fails to make you smile.That is Journey.  That is the game.Ankarath, wherever you are, thank you for walking with me.  May the winds ever be at your back.

I knew Journey is a great game,maybe one of the best video games in history,but...I didn't know why so many people moved by such a simple gameplay.I didn't know why people had a Journey-Fever,even players just bought PS3 only for this game.I didn't know how close a relationship could be in 100mins only.I didn't know how bad i wished to go back to the peak and stay with my friend i'll never meet again.Now I Know.â€œIt is better to walk with a friend in the dark than alone in the lightâ€ â€“ Helen KellerIt was an interesting experience for me, I had never played this game nor heard of it until recently. I went and looked at the store page, My Brother/Friend Ethan-Winters Just Told Me this game in the steam store now, so went ahead and bought it. After buying it, went and started up the game some day later. Went into the game, saw another model character that looks like mine, I thought it was an AI because I had thought it was a single player game. So I decided to play along with it, we went through the story, it progressed quite fast, mainly because we both did not really bother to check out other things. The more I played, the more I realized that the guy I was playing with was most definitely not an AI, it was a genuine player. As we went through the story, our cooperation got smoother, we no longer have a solo player attitude, we would signal to each other, wait for each other and walked, fly with each other. It was smoothing, relaxing, a truly unique experience. Even with the setbacks we had throughout our progression, we never gave up, we stuck together from the desert till the end, when one of us screwed up, we patiently waited for the other, chiming to the person where we are. I remember at the end, when i screwed up a jump and did not see the other player, I was genuinely scared, sad, I frantically searched for the person but to no avail. I was distraught, sad and disappointed but I continued onward. When I went up, there he was, chiming for me, assuring me that he had not left yet. I felt happy, comforted when I saw the person waiting for me and together we finished the story. I am not one to do reviews, but it was such a unique experience among my years of gaming that I had to share it. Thank you, punks for the experience, truly thank you. And thank you, for bothering to read my review.i'll never forget our journey kind stranger.This wasn't a game, it was an experience. I highly recommend you do this.

Journey is a unique gaming experience and I have played through it 3 times.  You can race through it the first time like I did or play again and search every nook and cranny.  I only managed 6 of the achievements.The lasting effect on me has been the music.  It was so sublime and emotional and enhances certain poignant moments in the game.  Skiing down sandy dunes at top speed, creeping through the underground, hiding from the guardians, bracing against the bitter wind and the jubilation at the end.....all carried by the soaring music.  Wonderful!Playing it co-op lifts the gaming experience.   When someone has been with you through thick and thin and you rejoice in reaching your destination.....that creates an unforgettable moment.  But you need to find that special someone who is with you, but allows you to experience the delights.  Too many players rushed ahead and did all the actions and I was left feeling like a damp squib.  I just pulled the plug on them and left the game. It is a fine line to 'help' someone and to 'dominate' the proceedings.Kudos to wonderful Syraris who was sooo patient with me.  He allowed me to bumble along and find everything myself.  When I was lost, he simply pointed in the right direction and rejoiced by chirping when I did it right.  Fighting through the snow, we walked side by side supporting one another and when I was blown off a building , he jumped right after me!  What a partner!!This is quite a graphically simple game with hidden delights.  Some of the scenery was beautiful.  Riding a whale was my highlight and I did enjoy tobogganing in the sand!  There are no fights but still a lot of danger to avoid.Buy the game and go along for the ride.  You won't regret it. 9/10
Maybe the real journey was the friends we made along the way
Bumped into a player, despite language barrier the person was super friendly and patient, credits rolls, i see that it's username is ILickPussies. Ah yes, the duality of man
Beautiful game that makes you oddly attached to the person you play with. Like a car driving in front of or behind you over a long distance and then part ways. It was an adorable experience.

To my nameless friend who did this Journey with me.First seeing you jumping in the distance, wondering who this person was who showed up in my game. But you called to me, you showed me how it worked. From there, we had fun sliding through the ruins, jumping and flying and skiing with glee. Together we hid amongst the columns, and gave each other courage to do that last slide through the cavern. We were free to be ourselves ourselves as we climbed the tower, each of us taking turns to show off. But then I lost you, you left. You disappeared. I trudged through the cold, feeling more alone than ever as I fought the elements.  But when hope was fading I found you again, and together, we took those last, weary steps. To the end. And what a glorious, beautiful, soaring end it was. I miss you friend, your supportive chimes, pointing out things I missed, always making sure we had each other in sight when things got difficult. You made the experience richer.This wasn't a game, it was an experience. I highly recommend you do this.

I'm 45, I've had good times and bad times.  I've fallen in love, grown up, gotten married, beaten alcoholism, had a child, fought off depression, led my wife through her kidney failure, carried the death of loved ones, and come back from the brink.  I've weathered the storm of life like anyone else . . . I'm not special.  I'm not rich, but comfortable, and I've gathered quite a steam library as a hobby over the last 10 years.  Something I have rarely done, during my time with almost 4000 titles, is write a review.  Two, maybe three for 4000 games.  Think about that for a second.I'm 45.  I just cried playing a video game, something I can't ever remember doing.  I feel like my heart is going to burst.  It's joy, and sadness.  It's like a good memory with a parent who's long gone, bubbled up at random, making you laugh and ache at the same time.  It's bittersweet.The music and visuals are subtle and flashy at the same time, they get under you and lift you up.  It's got spirit of the 60's, the heart of the 80's, and feels like every memorable video game trope from the 2000's, with the social softness of the 2020's.  It's huge and tiny at the same time, and thoughtfull and meditative together . . . it tells the story of leaving your comfort zone, and makes you comfortable.  It's heavy and light.  It's all of these and more.My emotions are a flood.  I had to write a review, and let people know how I feel.  I can't describe it, I feel like I found my heart again, and I didn't even know it was lost.  Life was comfortable before 2:00pm today . . . now it's magical.  It's these small things that I forget, and remember, and then forget again . . . the birth of my son, the feeling of nervous sweetness on my first date with my wife, an unexpected comment from a random stranger about my eyes, finding an old photo of my dad that no one ever remembered taking ---- This game is like that sweet, fleeting memory.TL.DR:  45-year old man cries after finding his heart lost in a game, and writes a review while his wife asks him if he's okay.11/10, would purchase these feels again.

There are a lot of feel-good games out there. There are games that put a smile on your face with touching moments, that warm your heart with intense charm, or simply give you something fun and uplifting to do. Sometimes itâ€™s too obvious what theyâ€™re doing, or there are sacrifices elsewhere to keep that cheerfulness going. And then thereâ€™s Sayonara Wild Hearts. Iâ€™ve played games that made me feel good but not many that were about feeling good, that could make me feel warm and fuzzy through their action, their music, their pacing, their themes, and everything in between. And I canâ€™t think of many that kick this much ass while lifting you up so effectively.Somewhere in the world, a young woman has had her heart broken. At the same time, the three major arcana that maintain harmony in the world have had their peace shattered by the appearance of a new arcana. With the last of their power, they grant the young woman the strength to stand against the arcana and her allies, to turn back the chaos and return harmony to the world. But the journey will be a perilous one, delving deep into realms of pure concept and emotion. With each victory the womanâ€™s heart grows stronger, and as she approaches the source of the darkness, she might find something else sheâ€™s been missing for far too long.Sayonara Wild Hearts wears its themes on the sleeves of its technicolor bomber jacket, but even if you donâ€™t pick up on them youâ€™ll get them nicely packaged for you by the finale. What this means for gameplay is about two dozen stages that follow the womanâ€™s intense plunge into Heartbreak Subspace, and emergence into the realms of the marauding arcana. Each of these stages is a breakneck rush through vibrant cities, forests, and freeways filled with hearts to collect and dangers to avoid. Theyâ€™re all quite different in their structures, as well. Sometimes youâ€™ll be gliding through space, sometimes tearing around on a motorcycle, sometimes leaping across collapsing roadways, or drifting in a muscle car, or flying on a sword, or clinging to a stag.Every single stage of this game is a beautiful cacophony of sights and sounds surging past you in intense new ways. Iâ€™m not kidding about the pace, either, because youâ€™ll usually only have a second or less to react to threats. What makes this work is the music, which always syncs with the flow of a stage. Obviously this will be important when you need to time button presses for leaps or strikes, but it can also signal sharp turns or big jumps ahead. The soundtrack is an intense mix of styles, just like the stages, with some marvelously voiced songs for the big showdown stages. Some of them are really quite heartfelt, and once the themes of the game start to connect with you itâ€™ll really click how much of an emotional journey it all is.I wish I could elaborate on that, but in the end Sayonara Wild Hearts is something you really, really need to experience for yourself. Itâ€™s not just the incredible soundtrack or the intensity of the gameplay. What makes this game special is how it builds all of its action and style to an emotional climax that can rival even the best-written games. Thereâ€™s a message here for anyone, anywhere, thatâ€™s all-inclusive and is sure to lift your spirits with its own power and the power of reaching that point yourself. Itâ€™s a fantastic way to spend an hour of your time, and thereâ€™s plenty more to do like getting score ranks, finding collectibles, and solving the gameâ€™s many riddles once youâ€™ve beaten it. But even without those bells and whistles, Iâ€™d keep coming back again and again. Not many games have made me feel so much like a superstar, or made me feel as good about it as this one.Did you enjoy this review? I certainly hope so, and I certainly hope you'll check out more of them at https://goldplatedgames.com/ or on my curation page!

TW// Self-Harm    This game is just as beautiful as when I first played it on a cold and dreary December 15th. Not knowing what I was getting into I bought this on a whim on the E-shop and it saved my life. Going through a very bad breakup SWH was the light at the end of the tunnel. Struggling with constant self-destruction and crippling depression this experience reminded me the importance of self-love, the need to forgive, to cry, to heal from my last relationship. The credits rolled. My eyes welled with tears as grief struck, but a wave of relief comforted me as I drifted off to sleep. The next day I recommended this game to all my friends and with an acquaintance from school. She absolutely loved it to bits and it got us talking about it's banging music, and the story. Now we have been happily together for three years! This woman has filled my life with so much joy and everyday I am so thankful to have her by my side. She has saved my life countless times, but none of this would have happened if not for the whole team behind SWH. No words can describe how grateful I am for what you have done for me and for everyone who has experienced this masterpiece.Thank you.From the bottom of my very being.You are worthy of love.One end is another beginning.Don't be afraid to begin again.Wild Hearts Never Die.             /  \  /  \           /            \           \            /             \        /               \    /                 V-Sayonara Wild Hearts! <3P.S. Thank you Queen Latifah for being iconic!P.P.S. Sorry this is a lot I just am very passionate and love this game 20/10 The game of all time.

I managed to get some time in with FtK: some just after full release and over the past couple of months.The review pretty much stands with some additions.1) The addition of the different modes (dungeon mode) and expanded content is great2) The changes to the chaos system (instead of a hard timer, specific events are on a timer which can be mitigated or even removed by a player's actions.3) Some interface and quality of life tweaks improved the game flow considerably.However, the game still suffers from "great mechanics cheaply implemented".So for my final recommendation: tentative buy! There's a lot of good play, humour and variation and you'll get a good amount of play time out of it.Just be prepared for some cheap shots (not simply difficult situations): when you can semi-reliably predict the outcome of a roll (gee, if I miss this shot which I've pumped up to 99% chance to hit, the last monster with 1 hit point will crit against my hero with 30 hit points left with 32 damage. Yup! It dodged. Yup, my healer is dead. Called it!), just shut it down for a while, work off the rage quit and come back until it all happens again.*** Original Review***I had a hard time determining if I should give "For the King" a thumbs up or down.There are a lot of really good things to say about this game. It has a really unique and colourful art style, some great music and a very fresh take on an RPG as a rogue-like.The systems that drive the game present a great blend of what you would normally find in a table-top style board game with the computer taking care of all the under-the-covers mechanics that can make those board games tedious. The devs have done a good job at realizing that the challenge from a game like this comes from the player having to make tough choices. Each "act" of each quest has a timer that, if it runs out, makes progress that much more difficult (the Chaos mechanic). Players must decide if they have enough time to go down into that cave to perhaps find loot and experience but risk elevating the danger inhibiting the ability to complete their main goals. Random encounters give the players a chance to receive a boon or bane, often having to weigh the odds and consequences of failure against the often unknown benefits of taking such risks. Resources such as cash, healing herbs, equipment, armor and weapons that match the ever more difficult monsters and encounters are rare and as the quest progresses, more expensive to buy in towns. And this is the first design point where I think  the developers don't trust their own systems enough. In the first act a healing herb (in limited supply to start with) costs about the same anmount of gold the player can get by winning one encounter. In the second act the cost increases not incrementally but by huge factor (about 5 times or so) and in futher acts this rises at the same exponential rate. So much so that buying even one healing herb is so prohibitive it isn't a consideration.While it does make sense that as the land becomes more perilous (and the monsters can drop more coin) such a steep ramp up actually removes a resource balance decision. There's no point in hoarding 10 gold to put to better armor or weapons later in the game when it won't even make a dent in buying a single healing herb. It also throws the suspension of disbelief when a single herb that restores action points is half the cost of an amazing weapon or set of armor. This extreme "inflation" seems to be implemented to fight in-game power creep instead of balancing out said creep. It also leads to a "single strategy" to buy up all the consumable resources you can early in the game and so makes the choice obvious (even required) rather than a decision to be made by the player. The combat system is very innovative. Each character has a set of stats and each weapon uses one of those stats. When attacking or using an ability, from one to five or six "coins" are shown and the RNG determies the success or failure of each "coin flip" based on the associated stat. For some abilities to be successful, all of the "coin flips" must be successful so the higher of number of successes needed the less of chance the action is a success. Players can also spend "focus" to assure that one or more of the coins come up a success and the player needs to balance using focus for critical situations. And here again is  where I think the developers need more confidence in their own designs.While the odds of each success and the odds of completing all coin successfully are displayed, I don't think the odds shown to the player are entirely accurate. I tested this out using some old fashioned card-counting and an abacus, which doesn't produce exact mathematical results but certainly points out some possible weightings over time. It seems that if players face higher-level monsters and some weapons, negative modifiers are applied to the roll but not displayed. I think this may be where some of the cries of cheating are coming from. The RNG seems very good in non-combat situations (such as overland challenges and disarming traps) so the discrepency seems very odd for just combat. This may just be a bug/oversight but if it is an intentional design decision, especially in a game so dependent on randomness, it masks an implemetaion issue and is point of frustration at design rather than a challenge of a game.The secondary attacks/abilities use the exact same system, but always have a lower chance of success (which is actually displayed) and usually require more successes than a normal attack. For example a basic stike could have three rolls at 67% per roll (inflicting some damage per success) but a special attack has five rolls at 47% each and requires each roll to succeed.  It's a bit of a double-whammy intended to push the player to use Focus which provides a challenge, but it also seems that even if the attempt is successful the monsters have a good chance to avoid the effect. While the game does display what effects the monsters are right-out immune to, far too often using special abilities instead of basic attacks have too low a chance of success and a waste of time when a basic attack has a better chance of at least doing something of use. The monsters follow the same system with a number of rolls and a number of potential successes. It seems though that even if the monster requires five successes to pull off a special attack, it does succeeds four out of five times. While the monsters should be better (and more dangerous) than the heroes, the incredibly high success rate of monsters especially when they need to make so many successes and do so easiliy, makes it seem like they are not subject to the same game rules as the player. It feels like, not so much cheating per se, but simply cheap.The developers have designed a good core mechanic but seem to go out of their way to work around it by configuring the system (incredibly high monster success thresholds, exteremely low success rates of secondary player abilities) to bypass their own design. It's almost a shame because it seems a re-evaluation of the power escalation as well as the configuation of the system (rather than the system itself which seems solid) would shift this perception significantly.Those mechanics, or rather the specific configurations of the mechanics, are to me what is holding back what is at its core a fantastic game.Overall I'd say that "For the King" has the potential to be the classic RPG rogue-lite in the same way FTL is for the space opera. With a better balance of - and trust in -  the mechanics the developers have implemented I would give this an enthusiastic thumbs up, but in it's current state that thumb is a very tentative. I'm still going to be playing and following the development of this game because of its potential for greatness.

DO NOT SLEEP ON THIS GAME. Seriously I had this game in my library forever and thought it would be just another "rogue-like" cash grab but I was so wrong. This game is what I wished that gloomhaven would be, and if that dosen't sell it for you then I don't know what will. The balance is so perfect where you always have to think and the punishing bad-luck moments are usually recoverable (if you plan ahead) . It scratches the dopamine roll itch very well too if you are the kind of guy who gets a little too into modifiable luck-adjacent mechanics (like dicey dungeons or auto-chess). One of my new all time favorites I'm confident to say.EDIT since I got the question about what I mean by cashgrab:In my opinion a cash-grab is when the game follows the exact same formula as an existing game without adding anything new into the mix. Like FIFA, most CoD/BF games (dosen't mean they all are the same but to me they are so I don't see the nuances) and so on. This game has a lot of sub-systems like economy, resource management, massive exploration, interesting loot to be gained in most interactions and so on. If the game was simply, as the screenshots led me to believe a "follow one of a few branching paths" and try to survive until the end like Slay the spire but without the deckbuilding I thought for a long time the experience would be bare-boned. Granted I start the review by saying do not sleep on this game since I did for so long. I know I did not give the game a chance and I regret that.Edit 2: Wow the questions I get are really interesting I'm thankful that we get a cool discussion going in the comment thread, check in if you want and feel free to ask me anything that confuses you.
Early Access Review

I absolutely love this game.Steam randomly recommended it to me, and it is by far the best random game buy I have ever made.Pros:* Extremely high replayability, every board is unique, and even 10 games in you will find equipment you have never seen before* Highly strategic decision making. Everything from how to spend your time/movement, to what rewards to pursue, to what pressing threat you should be addressing, matters. And that is just moving around the board, each combat is it's own puzzle to solve.* Tons of unlocks keep subsequent playthroughs fresh, without watering down the difficulty. Fun cosmetic options too.* Multiplayer/co-op supportConsThese are mostly nitpicks. Seriously, I love this game.* High variance spikes in RNG. The Focus Point system gives you a very strategic tool for limiting your exposure to bad rolls, but the catch is, FP is a very finite resource. And sometimes, you just get screwed. Part of the 'fun!' of challenging strategy games like this is learning how they work, and when you first start playing you don't know what you don't know. So when you get Ambushed and all your gold stolen, it feels unfair the first time it happens. However, from that point on you know that is thing that can happen, and it is on you to prepare for it.* Inconsistent shops. Anyone who has played Faster Than Light (which I also love) will probably know what I'm talking about, but one of the most frustrating things about that game (and this one) was the feast or famine with what items were *available to buy* from shops on any given run. Not whether or not you could afford what you wanted, whether or not the store had anything worth buying AT ALL. This game has that a bit too, and it can be pretty frustrating. I wish they would have made it so each biome had at least one guaranteed weapon and armor piece for each main attack stat between the two locations.* Games take a while to finish. The high replayability is nice, but it takes a few nights to finish a run. It would be cool if they  made a shorter game mode that tops out at level 5 and is completeable in a single sitting (like FTL).
