There is like 1 billion different Tower Defense games out there.Most use the conventional 2D top view to keep it simple.But there are some jewels that don't follow these old views.. jewels like Dungeon Defenders, Orcs Must Die and Sanctum!Sanctum 2 is definetly not an easy TD game but for sure a fun and challenging one!Playing this game in coop mode gets you the most out of it and it's also the most fun way to play the game in my opinion.If you like Tower Defense games, then Sanctum 2 is a MUST buy!

One could call this a reimagining of the original Sanctums run and gun tower defense gameplay.  For those who played the original changes include enemies that actively attack you if you get too close, walls are now low enough for towers to be able to shoot across multiple rows and also make it harder for you to avoid attacks. Most towers are air and ground now. Weapons are now split into classes, and you can only carry four tower types so as to encourage team-work.           For new players and beginners, if you enjoy FPS combat and Tower Defense, then this is a great fusion of the two. Balance is perfect between towers and player weapons so as to ensure contribution from both. You also have the option of inviting three other friends for a chaotic good time of setting up towers and shooting monsters in the face.

Action? CheckReaction? CheckIntensity? CheckCool aliens to shoot and not feel bad about it? CheckNot having to clean up the dead bodies after a good workout? CheckMaze building (and I don't mean having 2-3 options, I mean the whole nine yard of options)? CheckLOADS of diversified weapons, perks and towers? CheckSadly this game lacks in terms of the sizy of its community, and that's about the only bad thing I can come up about this game.You like fast-paced FPS Shooters? You like Tower Defense? You like to be faced with increasingly difficult odds and to put your name on some relevant leaderboards (until they reset them, of course)? Then this game's for you.I'm doing my part eradicating these filthy alien scums... are you?

All my life I have been empty. The doctors could not tell me why I was so depressed, and I never knew myself until today. I needed to experience my life as a goat. Goat Simulator has filled the void in my life.I knew as soon as I hit the truck with my goat that this was what I had been missing. I flew through the air in slow motion, tongue flying around, hitting the edge of the map and rebounding back, landing on (and falling through) the roof of a house. I could not get out, but that did not matter. I was treated with the ability to look down into the house beneath me, seeing the unsuspecting people casually sitting at their computers, oblivious to the sheer terror of the goat above them.Whether it was playing football with a basketball, swinging lampposts into groups of people or even doing 1080 degree flips, there was no limit to life as a goat. I didn't think it could get any better than this.I was wrong.As I jumped and screamed my way around the map, leaving a path of destruction in my wake, I happened upon a golden statue. Curiosity overtook me and I resisted the urge to grab it no longer. My life as a goat changed completely. I had a jetpack.I knew that this was meant to be, and what my mission from the Great Coffee Stain in the sky was. I was granted the supergoat power of being able to lift people and cars with my tongue. I could survive any impact. I could slow down time with mere thought. Now I could fly. It was time for world domination. Humanity had to be silenced so that the new goat overlords could reign supreme.All the humans are dead or enslaved. I have won. I am the goat, the goat is me.Go and goat this game. I kid you not, for mere bucks you can experience a sandbox like no other. Destruction, mayhem, death defying stunts. Seriously, there are more than 921 million goats in the world. Killing the humans was just part of the game. This is a SIMULATOR. Do you understand? A SIMULATOR. This can happen. There are enough goats out there to enslave us and/or kill us. It is your duty as a human to get this game, so that you may truly know your enemy. An enemy people do not take seriously, an enemy that we know nothing about. Coffee Stain studios have granted us the insight into the true terrifying reality of the impending Goatpocalypse. This is your weapon against the goats. Be prepared, for the goats are coming to get us.

So I was deciding whether to do a serious review on Goat Simulator because I haven't seen one on Steam. so rather than join the bandwagon of unfunny jokey reviews for the game, I'll stick to my guns...Goat Simulator does exactly what it says on the tin. you play as a Goat, You cause havoc wherever you go. trashing, bashing, causing explosions, destroying houses, jumping on trampolines, basically anything you want. With plenty of interactive objects in the game, you can spend plenty of time wandering around never finding a dull moment. The graphics in goat simulator are really nice. They aren't on the levels of Evolve or something, but for this type of game, you aren't really going to be playing for the top of the range graphics.  The music and audio are exactly what you would expect here. derpy music in the background as you potter about the city, along with cries of fear from the civilians as the demon goat runs rampant.There are three different areas in Goat Simulator. each zone is huge, ranging from theme parks, to crop fields, every building has something to do in it, every room has something to interact with or destroy. I honestly don't think there is anything wrong with either of the levels included here.  There is nothing difficult in the game to do here at all. There are no real objectives, just an open world sandbox game where you do whatever you want, whenever you want. I have managed to put about twenty hours into Goat Simulator. most of this time was playing on local screen co-op with my girlfriend, and then a couple more hoursâ€™ achievement hunting, and boy there is some pretty ridiculous achievements to do. Other than the developers openly coming out stating that they would not be fixing any bugs in the game, I had no real game breaking bugs, apart from sometimes falling through the world. however this was fixed easily by just respawning again. If you want a game that is just purely for messing around in with no real aim and wanting some real stupidity, then Goat Simulator will give you plenty of fun. granted this type of game is not for everyone, I enjoyed it though. Tom's Score Card1) Stay away2) Not Recommended3) Only recommended when on sale4) Recommended5) Highly recommended6) This is a must playIf you would like to follow my reviews more easily, be sure to join my group by clicking here.

This game is an unfortunate victim to overhype. I bought this game while it was still in Alpha 1, and the finished product is almost unrecognizable in a bad way. At its first conception in the pre-alpha, the game was merely about you being a nosy neighbor and wanting to discover what was behind your neighbor's basement door. Nothing in the game was too extreme regarding its wackiness, but had tiny doses of absurdity that would pique your interest (for example the unique house design or a flooded room upstairs with a robotic shark on patrol for trespassers). Now this change isnâ€™t necessarily a bad one in theory as the developers opted out of the semi-realistic world for a much more heavily stylized one. This change in and of itself is not bad, and certainly gives the game an identifiable look. Some think that the games look is now ugly, however this point I disagree with and I do believe the game looks good and that the developers did a respectable job with the new aesthetic. The major problems with the game can be broken up as follows.-GAME SETTINGS-It is the year 2017, for a game to come out in this day and age with no options to re-bind keys or have a windowed mode is unacceptable, especially the former. -THE AI-One of the chief reasons I, and many people I believe, were so interested in this game at first was the AI. The biggest selling point for the pre-alpha was the adaptive AI that would learn how you would traverse the house and react accordingly. Whether that be by boarding up a window you broke, blocking a door, placing a bear trap etc. In the earlier builds of the game, the AI seemed to do this decently enough for an alpha build of the game. However, it seems like this was placed on the backburner as the AI appears to simply spam traps and security cameras and endlessly patrol the entire premises. Another big point about the AI was the three modes that it would operate in. In a video on tinyBuildâ€™s channel, they went into detail how the AI had three modes, them being idle, hunt and attack. While hunt and attack are self-explanatory, the biggest downgrade was the idle mode. The idle mode is where the neighborâ€™s AI would live a normal life such as watching TV, sleeping, taking a shower etc. In the final build of the game this mode seems non-existent. The only thing the neighbor has done in my experience is turn on the TV (not actually sitting down to watch it) and sleeping. Whereas in the earlier builds he would do more such as the aforementioned taking a shower, drinking milk, or doing repairs on his car. Instead, the neighbor spends most his day aimlessly patrolling around his house. Another major issue is the bi-polar behavior of the AI. One moment the AI will be completely brain dead, and at another point will be an omnipresent nuisance.-BUGS-As the original release date in August for the game approached, and after the flop of the last beta build, it become worrying the state the game was in at release. However, the developers decided to delay the gameâ€™s release until December 8. This was originally seen as a good thing, as it was assumed that all the problems the community had brought up would be addressed and fixed. Such was not the case and there have been many reports game breaking bugs. Credit where it is due, since the developers have been releasing patches consistently since launch, however with a nearly 3-month delay, one would think these would have been already fixed along with the previously mentioned problems. -INCOHERENT STORY-Sadly, the story almost seems like a last-minute addition. The story is given to you in little sequences, and while they give you some insight, are incredibly cryptic. It isnâ€™t so much the game is trying to tell you a story, but rather you must go and look for it. While some people enjoy theory crafting, for those who donâ€™t, you are stuck having to fill in major gaps on your own and almost making up your own story. Due to the storyâ€™s cryptic nature it often makes no sense, and arguably could be completely left to interpretation. As much as I loved this game at the beginning and wished for the best, it sadly has fallen flat. Hello Neighbor takes a very interesting idea with lots of promise and executes it poorly. As of writing this review the developers are releasing patches consistently, which could lead to the issues being solved. As of now however, and especially at the current asking price of $30, it is advised that you stay on your side of the street, and pass on this one.

Lets dive into some history of me buying this game.All that time ago alpha 1 came out. It was like a big thing for youtubers. So I paid the price of admission, $29.99. I mean it looked like a good game and it claimed to have advanced AI. I saw no problem.           As the alpha's and beta's came out each build was different from the last so I assumed that either...A. the developers were trying to confuse us to make us not anticipate the big amazing game that was coming at the release date.B. They were not satasfyed with any build so they kept changing it.C. It was all a part of one big story or something.At the beginning of summer 2017 the official release date was announced. I was excited and at the end of the summer came its supposed release. August 25th came and so did a delay. turns out the game would not be reased till December 8th. This made me worried. Delays are never good. I just shrugged it off and just assumed they were fixing bugs. December 8th came and so did the actual game. Not another delay (Im looking at you, Mirrors edge Catalyst).I downloaded and launched the game. It looked like there was a story. I played it in offline mode so thats why I had .2 hours in game.  Now is when I realize that I wasted my money. The AI is not what the Dev's claimed it would be. I want the first Alpha versions AI back. It did what the Dev's told us it would do. It lounged it borded up our entrances and layed traps at the places we entered.Now we have this paranoid creep. All he does is spam traps and cameras and guard his house. The house in the first level is so small that no matter where you are the neighbor is on top of you the entire time. I couldnt even go near the house without him hearing me and chasing me away. In other levels there are these stupid confusing puzzles. I will use IGN's example "I had to freeze a pool of water by putting a globe recovered from an obscure corner of the house (which was its own illogical adventure) in the neighborâ€™s freezer on a completely different floor, then placing it on a random pedestal."My point is that this game sucks. It has just sat in my library gathering dust.  DO NOT BUY IT, DO NOT MAKE THE SAME MISTAKE I DID. PLEASE SAVE YOUR MONEY. Buy a nintendo switch instead thats much better but DO NOT GET THIS GAME FOR THE SWITCH BECAUSE IT IS MAKING ITS WAY ONTO THE SWITCH.This is my review for this horrible mess.

There is nothing worse than a game making you feel like an idiot for not understanding what to do or how it works. But to be fair, I don't think the game itself knows what's going on half the time. The first couple encounters with the house are straight forward enough, breaking the player into the madness that is Dr. Seuss's fever dream. Then it just goes off the rails with the size, complexity, and lunacy. This would not be a big issue...except for the main point of the game, which is the neighbor himself and the fact you're under constant stress of not getting caught by his broken and oversensitive AI, which makes doing anything either a game of cat and mouse or borderline impossible. Imagine trying to navigate your way around a maze with trick shot level jumping, unstable stacking puzzles, and a hundred hidden switches and keys while constantly walking through glue and hearing bumbumbumbumbumbumbumbumbumbumbumbumbumbum nonstop...and you mess up, get caught, thrown out of the house, have to find your way back to that part of the house, and figure out how to proceed. Rinse/repeat. That is this game. There are some segments in between dealing with the house that break up the gameplay a bit but follow a similar trend to the rest of the game with their own sets of issues.Which all leads to an ending that, in my opinion, feels like someone kicked you to the ground and laughed about it.The best way I can sum the game up is this: Creative but infuriatingly and fundamentally flawed.This was not fun to play and I found nothing of significance to take away here.

Party Hard 2   It's 3am, let me sleep   ğŸ“‹ Premise  Published by tinyBuild and developed by Pinokl Games and Kverta, Party Hard 2 has received many conflicting opinions ever since it came out. It's one of those games that you either like or hate. At the core, Party Hard 2 is still very similar to its predecessor, benefitting however from more polished mechanics and additions to the gameplay. It's an action-stealth based game that requires the player to progress throughout different scenarios, completing a variety of objectives. While there's no real story, the game still tries to give the player a reason as to why you will just be going around from nightclub to nightclub killing people. In reality, it's just a means thanks to which the levels are tethered together. âœ… Pros:  â€¢ Engrossing gameplayâ€¢ Huge maps â€¢ A multiplicity of objects the player can interact withâ€¢ Funny and bizarre situationsâ€¢ Gives the opportunity for the player to plan ahead of time â Cons:  â€¢ Extremely repetitive gameplayâ€¢ The whole stealth drive of the game limits the player a lotâ€¢ Objectives don't seem to vary much from level to level ğŸ® Gameplay: in depth   General information  Upon starting Party Hard 2 you're given the possibility of deciding whom your killer is going to be. It's in the form of "characters" that the game offers you different difficulty modes: "The Wannabe", who's perfect for a more relaxed and casual gameplay but at the same time doesn't allow the player to unlock achievements. "Party Hard Killer", which is the character that the game is meant to be played as and gives a medium challenge throughout the levels. "Kao Tech" and a "Panda" cosplayer which both offer a more challenging as well as funny and unusual gameplay style. While in the selection screen the game does require you to pick Medium or Hard difficulty, the character you'll choose will make a huge difference.Party Hard 2's overall challenge increases the more you progress through the game, and while the core mechanics remain the same, it still manages to get more and more frustrating. In each map, you'll notice you'll have some objectives you're forced to complete before being able to evacuate, and some others you could complete instead of the main ones, but aren't forced to. The majority of the objectives in the game require you to kill either all the partygoers or a few selected targets who will be pointed out with a big red arrow above their heads. To do so the game gives us a huge spectrum of objects to interact with around you.Finding them at first glance would be hard, but thankfully Party Hard 2 arms you with the Killer Instinct, which allows you to scan your surroundings. Green items are the ones that can be picked up or interacted with in order to make deadly traps and weapons to kill your unsuspecting victims, orange ones are NPCs with a special role to them, like bodyguards and janitors, and red ones are your primary targets.While the game is incredibly straightforward in the way it's meant to be played and the objectives it provides you with, at least the ways you can go about your murders aren't. There are a few funny mechanics in Party Hard 2 worth mentioning, for example, the astonishing amount of hidden events you can trigger if you just take your time interacting with posters, or the random Terminator that spawns in the map at times with the sole objective of killing you to protect their target.There's never only one set way for you to kill your victims. You could get yourself the materials you need to craft a molotov, have the speakers on the dancefloor explode, spill water near the DJ console in order to electrocute everyone. However, it's not easy to make any of these things happen, and while the game usually rewards the ones that plan ahead of time, it punishes them just as much. You could be following a victim for 2 minutes or 10 minutes without them ever stopping anywhere remotely close to anything you could use to create an unfortunate accident or nowhere secluded for you to use your knife and end their life.Even when you think you're far away enough, or at least out of sight, the game obviously seems to believe otherwise. One of the biggest problems with Party Hard 2 at the moment is probably the very faulty AI and the unclear safe distance after which other partygoers can't see you commit a murder. Most times you'll be safe when taking care of someone standing alone behind other people, and other times they will still spot you even if they aren't directly looking at you. While you might think that this is fine and it just adds more spice to the challenge, it's probably worth mentioning that once the partygoers call the cops, there is no challenge at all as you are unable to actively kill them or slow them down. Partygoers also seem to be able to connect you with a recently happened explosion or death if you're standing too close to the scene, which is completely normal, until they call cops on you even when you're three rooms away.Party Hard 2 is a game that uses the stealthy, mostly frustrating, challenge as it's strong point, and it's a formula that would work if all the small bugs that undermine it wouldn't make the challenge almost exasperating ruining that frustration = challenge equation that has otherwise worked for other games in the industry. Content  Generally, each level doesn't take more than 10 minutes, 15 tops, to be completed, which would make it a fairly short game. However, the fact that you most likely won't be doing a scenario just that one time, but multiple times, adds to the total gameplay, at the cost of the enjoyment of the game itself. ğŸ”¬ Technical Analysis   Graphics  The polished pixeled art style seems to fit just fine in a game like Party Hard 2, and it is also a huge step up from its predecessor's graphics. It's easy to notice with how much attention each map was made in order to allow the player to spot objects with more ease. Sound  The tunes are fitting: they're upbeat and fast-paced, typical of nightclub environments. Performance It's a relatively small game and therefore doesn't consume much resources wise. No framerate issues were experiencedl Bugs Encountered  Sometimes the hidden events wouldn't trigger. Other times activating the Steam overlay would lock my characters into being able to only move in one direction. In my experience, I was only able to fix this by restarting the game. ğŸ¬ Wrapping up  Party Hard 2 is the perfect sequel to Party Hard, bringing in a completely revisited art style and new mechanics to the plate, but it still fails to deliver a refreshing gaming experience that could keep you hooked for hours on end. Base price being 17â‚¬ I can highly recommend this purchase to fans that are sure to love the stealth based genre, and suggest to every other interested party to give the game a chance.  ğŸ“ˆ RATING: 7/10  This product was reviewed with a key provided for free by the developers.Follow our curator page, OCG-Curations if you like and want to see more reviews like this one.

I liked the first party hard but this game does not have the same charm.- The soundtrack is not as good as the first game and to make things worse songs are repeated throughout the game unlike in the original where each stage had it's own unique track.- The game is buggy and slow, especially during cut-scenes and I have experienced crashes - Some levels have  very frustrating designs. Especially the motel level, which is filled with goons which will instantly kill you if you step near them. - The controls are often unresponsive. There have been several times where I have been mashing the attack button at a critical moment and my knife attack doesn't come out, causing me to get a game over.  - The plot of the game doesn't make sense. In the original game the party hard killer didn't need a reason to kill anybody, now he want's revenge against a pharmaceutical company he apparently worked for? Overall this game is not a satisfying follow up to the original and certainly not worth the price tag

Party Hard 2 is a Hitman-ish game about mass-murdering annoying party-goers that disturb you in the night. Video Co-op Previewhttps://www.youtube.com/watch?v=u32bgmwJlGc Written Review Each level puts you in a new environment, where you are tasked to kill specific targets.It's easy enough to pick them out from the crowd, but you can also hold your "instinct" button to get an overlay that highlights all targets as well as interactable objects.Once you've reached your target, you'll need to find an opportune time and way to kill them without being caught. You can make kills look like accidents by sending off rogue vehicles to run people over, or setting an oven to explode. If you happen to be seen, you'll have the chance to kill the witnesses before they call the cops. If you don't manage to stop them, the police will arrive at the scene and start to look for you. Even if you weren't seen committing the crime, dead bodies will still get the cops to be called, however they won't arrest you on sight without any proof.What I love about the game is how unpredictable it can be. Once, I was caught by the cops, and someone randomly started to beat them up as they carried me to the cop car, which allowed me to run free. Levels are slightly randomised, so upon replaying one you might have a different experience. The layout stays the same, but smaller things can differ like NPC positioning and attitudes.One thing I like about the game, is it's quite funny considering it's a game about mass-murder. Random funny NPCs might drop in for cameos, dialogue between characters can be amusing, and the unpredictable AI can make for some memorable scenes.Aside from the obvious stab to the back, or sabotaging an object to land kills, you can also craft items together. For example, a gasoline tank and a bottle will create a molotov cocktail that can be thrown from the distance at a trail of gas you might have left behind. It's just another nice addition to the variety of kills.There are also optional objectives that are fun to seek out, and might be an incentive for completionists to replay the game.Lastly, the aesthetic and music really help convey the atmosphere. The game consists of 2D sprites on top of a 3D background with full lighting and shadows, which looks really awesome in my opinion. The music is also a great listen, and had me bobbing my head the whole time.Overall, I'm really enjoying the game in both solo and co-op, and definitely recommend it to the kind of player that enjoys patiently observing and waiting for the right time to strike! I plan to play it to completion.

A surprisingly intense little game.Youtuber packs and cartoony style made this game easy to underestimate and overlook. But upon putting some time into it I was pleasantly surprised. The idea is simple, 2D platform quicker than your opponents. If you're fast enough that you run them off the screen you win. Double jumps, slides, grappling hooks, power-ups, and an eventual shrinking screen size add fun spontaneity to the looping levels. It makes for some very intensely competitive local or online multiplayer of 2 to 4 players. Though online play, even ranked matchmaking, will more likely than not yield at least one opponent that de-ranked on purpose to just methodically follow the same memorized 'best' path  of a level to dominate new blood. Not too thrilling.But, I'm very much more of a singleplayer fella and the campaign provided a mere few hours of fun.  Good fun though. The AI can be a bit robotic and uninteresting but hard mode still made for a decent challenge that got intense at times. And "unfair" difficulty is even there for the masochists. All the leveling up and XP earned just unlocks multiplayer perks like levels, characters and skins. So there isn't much motivation there for me to re-play and continue to rack up the XP beyond one hard mode playthrough. Overall its a fun little game and will be added to my living room system for local multiplayer fun. Other than that there's nothing left for me at the moment. I did have some fun though. I definitely recommend it in a bundle or 66+ % off.  Worth noting that the online community is still quite active/populated despite the people slumming in lower ranks. And workshop levels make for less methodical memorization opponents, but you still need the cooperation of the lobby to vote for said levels. Either way, all the online play stuff is something one could get into for sure. Gotta go fast!

This game starts off promisingly. It has all the right elements needed to make a good management game--and I love management games! But the thing is, unlike most management games, Fight Club doesn't want me to succeed. It wants me to fail. At its simplest definition, the goal here is to improve your stats (and skills) to win matches. However, your stats degrade at great amounts everyday. So the challenge here is to train and train to increase your stats more than they decrease. The problem is they decrease A LOT, and the game puts forward ridiculous barriers to seemingly make sure that even at your best, your stats increase at the slowest pace possible (and at your worst, they actually decrease). Just to illustrate:- The job that pays the most pays $50 per round and the other job closer to your house pays $30, but the most efficient food costs $20 and fills up less than half of your food meter.- Having a sparring match with your trainer to get skill points costs $20.- The gym costs $10 per entry- If you earn more than $250, you get robbed, because this game does not want you to ever accumulate money.- You can only store 7 pieces of each food item, so it doesn't want you to accumulate food either.- All of these are located in different areas which takes time to get to, and the more you waste the hours of your day walking around, the more your stats decrease.This results in a lot of grinding and managing your time and money PERFECTLY just to make sure your stats don't decrease more than they increase. And that's fine. I'm fine with grinding, and management games are called that because it's all about managing your resources efficiently. My problem with this in this game is that it gets disheartening. It wants you to regress as hard as it can. It wants you to save $250 to get that gym equipment only to be robbed on the way to the store. It wants you to prepare for your match and reach 15 agility only to reach the next day and be back at 14. It wants you to meticulously plan your day, only to be dragged into an event you didn't expect and get beaten by a much harder opponent and lose bars you've worked hard to fill. This is that rare management game that wants to rob you of that feeling of progression.I stuck through this game because I thought it would get better once you get stronger. It didn't. The stats just get harder to train and easier to lose. I eventually gave up near the end thinking that I've wasted my time.

Rating: good (7/10) Introduction Punch Club is an oldschool arcade fighting manager. I dont call it simulator, because you dont actually fight with your character, you only train it and decide, how it will become stronger. Gameplay & Story: 7/10 The story is something from the Kung-Fu 90s movies - you are to avenge your fathers death so you have to train harder and become one of the champions to challenge the bad guy. The gameplay takes a bit getting used to and there are actually quite few tricks you have to find out, before managing to proceed further with story. The gameplay is based around managing your character, deciding when to fight, train, eat, sleep and work for money. The story is really well combined with side quests - you feel like every character in the game has its place and is somehow connected to your main story. Besides that, you will have some decisions in the game, that will change how you will proceed and finish the game. There are two main quest lines of which you can pick only one. The ending is not absolutely satisfying, but the road there was much fun and some side-quests had nice dialogs and the reference to famous fighting movies, games and super-heroes magazines are amazing.  Combat & Challenge : 8/10 The combat in Punch Club is heavely luck based, especially if you take agility based builds. You can win a fight without taking a single blow and knocking your opponent in the first round, but you can also lose without hitting the enemy once because "RNGesus" is spitting on you. It is nice you can speed up the combat to x4 speed because when farming achievements or replaying the game it gets boring to watch the passive fights. Since you cannot control anything during the fight itself, the only thing to do for you is swapping the skills between rounds if needed or getting the experience which skills to get next to beat the opponent you lost against.The game is quite challanging because of "stat decay", that means your fighting abilities dwell over time, so you have to carefully plan when to train and when to work for cash to be able to feed yourself. If you play the game on "Hard", it gonna definetely take some time to beat it especially if its your first run. Graphic & Interface : 6/10 Retro style graphic absolutely fit the game and there are some nice details here and there to look for. The small details greatly increase the immersion and make the game more fun (for example take a look at who is standing outside Apu's shop, or the pictures hanging in some houses, etc.). The interface is simple and offers not many functions, maybe lacking a bit in flexibility. It would be nice to set-up how many hours you want to train on a bench or to what exhaustion level you want to work. The game is based around decisions made for your character, but the interface does not provide all needed tools for perfection. Progress & Mini-Games : 6/10 The progress depends heavily on the difficulty you picked. On the hardest difficulty the progress becomes quite grindy, since you have to "work, eat, sleep, repeat" a lot. Then you lock yourself for few days in the gym training to be able to take 1-2 fights and you are out of cash again, so the cycle starts again.On the middle difficulty the progress is much quicker, so it is possible to finish the game in few hours achieving the hidden 100 days achievement. Sadly, on certain phases of the game it does not let you progress quick enough by holding back the fights telling you the opponent gonna be "read in few days". It slows you down unnessesary, but gives you some more time for training.There are no activities to be considered mini-games in Punch Club, so this point is not taken into rating. Audio & Immersion : 7/10 The music and audio in generel absolutely fit the style of the game. Retro sounds to retro graphics make you feel like playing this old coin machines that were standing in clubs in the 90s. The game has nice details for immersion, some side effects like flashing graphics and squicky sounds that increase the immersion effect at the right spots in the game. Side-Notes This game is single player only.This game contains steam achievements.This game offers replayability for further 2-3 runs. You can either try the other side of the story or different skill builds.This game offers some play time for its price - it took me 30 hours to finish the game twice on both story sides including one hardcore run and getting most achievements. Summary Punch Club is so far the best fighting manager in retro look. The game has great feeling and immersion, especially if you loved oldschool Kung-Fu or fighting movies and has tons of references to movies and characters somehow connected to fighting. It offers nice challenge, replayability value and impactful story decisions.I hope this review helps you making the decision if its worth buying this game. Rate and leave a comment if you enjoyed reading it.~ForestWolf

TL:DR:Punch Club is a very cool game, but after a while, not a very fun game. It's rough around the edges and is best purchased on sale or from a bundle.Pros:+Art style is sweet+Packed with references+Some level of interesting story progression and choices to makeCons:-Grinding for food and stats-Bugs (I've encountered around nine or ten so far)-Lack of information for certain thingsLet me start off by saying that the art style, the music, and the references all are very nice and support lasting interest in this game. There's been a couple times where I've chuckled and even more where I've gotten into the music or been impressed by something that's been drawn.The story progression is rough around the edges but over-all has some choices to be made and should capture some level of interest no matter what.I am currently around 7.5 hours into the game, and up to about the 6.5 hour mark, I was really enjoying it. I was lucky enough to get over the early-on robbery hurdle that everybody else has been having trouble with, but now that I've gotten to this point, I can't progress any more without investing more time than it's worth.The biggest flaw that I have seen bringing this game down is the stat loss system. In the beginning of the game it's a minimal impact mechanic to extend the length of the game and make sure you have more to balance, but by halfway through it will leave you grinding like crazy just to hold your stats where they are. I spend all day everyday training currently, and my stats stay around the same area meaning that I cannot handle any larger fights and progress in the game.With this, I will sometimes encounter bugs when I'm trying to travel to buy more energy drinks that require a game restart, or being told to visit the Don on three seperate occasions by people, and every time having him act like he's never met me. Who knows, maybe he has amnesia.The last of the issues I encountered, and so far probably the least impactful is the lack of information. At the beginning it was very difficult to get started because besides the small training manual you're given, there is very little information on where to start, meaning you'll probably end up eating at least a few rotten burgers from the trash outside the bar.Over-all, I would rate this game a 6.5/10, given that it has a lot of potential, but just falls short due to the grind-essential nature of the training mechanic. I don't know if I will be playing this game again any time soon, but it was fun while it lasted, just up to where I've left off.Thanks for reading.
It's tamagotchi sort of game where you train cage fighter

I feel bad giving this game a negative review because I really wanted to love it. I loved all the TV and movie references sprinkled around the world (Fight Club, Rocky, Snatch, TMNT, Pulp Fiction, etc, etc.) I just felt ultimately everything gets way too repetitive. The training and working you have to be in a constant balancing act doing days and days and days of keeping stats and money in check while making sure you have enough food to be able to not starve. Just seems like way too much time doing this stuff instead of getting to fight. The fighting feels pretty shallow too, overall. Didn't thrill me at all. Also, no variety in music. After a couple hours I had to just mute the music and play my own so I didn't blow my brains out.

A very entrtaining fighting managment game, the devs have quickly addresed some small issues with the banacing that were there at launch.The game plays a cross between game dev tychoon and an fighting rpg with the looks of an old lucasarts adventure title.Anyone who enjoyes 90's action movie referances and music will get a huge kick out of this too.All in all a great little title.

If you want to win, go way of the Tiger with an agility build. If you want to take longer to win than your base building sessions in Fallout 4, then by all means, pick the other two inferior paths. I really want to like this game, because it's art style, music and call backs to 80 - 90's martial arts movies makes the game quite charming and enjoyable. It's a tragic shame that four severe factors corrodes this enjoyment: 1.The crippling stat decay system: training or not, your progress will drop by roughly 50 % everyday regardless.  Either the devs never exercised in their lives or they REALLY wanted to add micro payments in their game to mitigate this effect but were deathly afraid of having their small building burned to the ground.  2.Disappointing story for the champion path:  If you wanna play a hero, look elsewhere, because the game will punish you by eventually becoming a commercialized tool instead of a boxer and have a weak as heck ending to top it off. If this was supposed to be a nod to Rocky 3, then they nodded so hard, their nose busted on the counter.  3.RNG: Aside from picking your moves before the fight, you have no control of combat whatsoever, you have to pray to RNGesus that your fighter not only attacks, but follow up with more afterwards and not stare into his opponent's eyes likes he's falling in love.  4.Severe balance issues:  Like I said, if you want the less stressful path possible, then go agility, because having to hit and avoid damage is far more preferrable than taking hits as the RNG system screws you over because your fighter felt like taking hits than giving them, running out of stamina and eventually losing. The more strength you have the more tired you get, as stamina doesn't regenerate as much as it should, unless you have skills that increase your chances as you get up from the floor.  There is, of course the common complaint of repetiveness of going through your "simmy" routines, but if these four glaring issues were mostly addressed, I would of forgave this.  Unfortunately it only adds to the tedium of this game.If you want to buy this game for the call backs and asthetics, I won't stop you, but you've have been warned.

Great fighter management game, an ode to Rocky and many 80's and early 90's tv phenomena. Now is the time to clear this from backlog! Punch Club 2 released a week ago, a perfect time to check out the original, I thought. Turns out yes it is! The title still holds up with its art and gameplay! This game has been offered many times through bundles, so many people own it already. If you don't own it yet, it's about â‚¬2,50 during sales. Weirdly enough not now with the launch of the new installation. Punch Club In this game you're a beginning fighter who wants revenge for his father. You can join fighting leagues, street fights, and ascend the ranks in all of them. Meanwhile you have to train hard, and keeping up with your energy and calories. Which means you have to work for money, which takes valuable time, and not training decreases your fitness. The game is rather forgiving, you can't die. If you lose, it mostly means it will take more time. If you run out of food and money you can always eat that rotten hamburger from the trash, you'll be fine! And the game is fair in length. It keeps the story going with a nice pace. Winning fights give talent points, which you can put into three paths. Strength, Agility and Stamina. These are also the stats you're training to increase. Before fights you can assign skills, and you see the skills your opponent uses. So you can somewhat counter your opponents, which means in reality omit some skills they are countering, for example versus block breakers omitting blocks. Conclusion A great game! It's a perfect game to spend 15-20 hours with. Full with references, that I won't spoil. If you were part of those eras, you will definitely enjoy this. If you're a millennial or younger, I'm not sure if this is very funny. Parts that I liked slightly less were working jobs, there is a moment the protagonist returned from abroad, and there were no jobs available except for the two basic ones. It felt like a bug. Speaking of bugs, one time my house disappeared. Turns out I hadn't triggered an event and was able to spawn it afterwards, but still this should have been patched. The title rolls neatly from the tongue, however you're not in a club at all. Because of the title I had a different expectation of the game. And lastly it's very unclear how effective skills are. The game does give a hitpercentage of skills, but it would be far more useful to see damage per energy. I played this to see if part 2 would be for me, now I know it is. Not right now, my backlog is huge :)84/100More reviews at Omnivore Gamer, games that are easy to control (for handicapped gamers).

This games hard to review because I love the game but I understand where others have stated and indicated their concerns, it's a game that needs to be optimised from the beginning (regarding player input), this doesn't mean it's bad. It's just not clearly indicated to the player in a fair manner.Yes I love this game and put a whole load of time into it but many people will go in with the idea it's a simple resource-management game with extra interactions tacked on. It simply isn't however, it's a pure to the genre min-max game in which you're to know what to do and when to do it off the bat - there's no middle-ground sadly. I made a huge error first time playing this game and luckily for both myself and the dev's I had the time and willingness to spend to restart and do the whole game a-fresh. Not everyone is willing enough to do this, and I don't disrespect that.Either way, I came to love this game and for it a love for Lazy Bear Games as a developer - however with all caveats listed yes I give this game a thumbs-up and recommend it along with Lazy Bear Games as Dev's but I am totally empathetic to anyone that dislikes this game and so it feels only fair to state this game is likely to have a fair but somewhat niche audience that will truly love it for what it is.

Do not be fooled by the store page. this game is not a fun little resource-management game but a hardcore min-max experience. If you do not plan out your days like Batman plans out the twelve different ways he's going to disable the first jaywalker he sees next month, you will fail.I feel like there's a fun game in here somewhere, but it is buried under multiple layers of mild annoyances that all add up to the end result of an incredibly infuriating experience. Stat Decay: Yeah, it's annoying as hell. The game is balanced around this mechanic dogging your every step throughout any given playthrough, and working around it never feels fun. it feels like you're barely keeping your head above water even if you spend an entire day just training, to say nothing of simultaneously having to take time to work, get paid, feed yourself and keep your energy up, none of which halt the decay.Story: The first annoyance is that the entire thing is basically one endless stream of 80s American pop culture references awkwardly crammed together into a single, nigh-incomprehensible package. I love it when stories don't take themselves too seriously and are willing to have fun, but Far Cry: Blood Dragon executed this particular theme astronomically better. Maybe this stuff is funnier to Russian players and got lost in translation. I couldn't tell you.The second annoyance is that the game features multiple routes for you to take, but there is no way to skip or fast-forward interactions you've already seen on subsequent playthroughs. The game also gives you very little agency in which story routes to activate. it will frequently wrest control from you and force you into side stories you may or may not be interested in, and will occasionally even throw you into a fight with no warning whatsoever, often right after you just finished another fight and are weakened from stat loss.This is particularly noticeable in regards to "The Dark Fist" storyline, which was previously a DLC (and therefore optional) but is now baked into the base game and forced upon you with no choice. ANY playthrough of the game now will REQUIRE you to dedicate a significant portion of your time to difficult battles from this DLC. These DLC interactions are automatically triggered whenever you go home, which is the only place you can efficiently recover energy and heal after a fight.Everything Else: You've essentially got three style to choose from when building your fighter, and while they are all viable they aren't particularly well balanced. A bear build is fun but risky, and a pain to train for. a turtle build is interesting but slow to start (go figure). and a tiger build has high accuracy and dodge, plus several ways to make enemies hurt themselves. I think you can see the issue there.I feel bad for writing this horrendous wall of text and just criticizing the game so harshly, but as much as I want to be able to enjoy this silly 80s pop-culture boxing management game, it does everything within its power to annoy the â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ out of me and stop me from enjoying it. I sincerely hope the upcoming sequel respects the player a bit more and spends more time getting out of the way and letting people enjoy it.

this is the type of game i dreamed of making as a small child. it invokes that feeling when your looking out a car window imagining mario jumping from fence to fence as your drive by the landscape. its just so good and raw and pure and classic but at the same time nothing really tried to it anywhere near like this before. the musics great. the controlls feel wonderfull. this game is amazing.

GOTTA GO FAST!When I first heard of Clustertruck it seemed like a silly game that would only entertain me for 5 minutes at best. Boy was I wrong, not only is Clustertruck an extremely fun adrenaline rush with great replayability, but it also got me hooked to the point that I played through all the levels in one sitting. All there is to this game is jumping from truck to truck while dodging obstacles, which can sound quite boring, but the real fun starts when you treat it as a parkour speedrunning game by trying to complete everything as fast as you can. Went through all the levels? Buy some upgrades and do it again. Upgrades sometimes drastically change the way you play by adding interesting mechanics. Completed it again? Get some friends together and challenge eachother, see who can beat a level the fastest.TL.DR: For being such a simple game, Clustertruck is a surprisingly fun and replayable parkour speedrunning game. I highly recommend anyone who is on the fence to give it a try.

TL.DRGreat strategic 'island defense' game to play in quick sessions.Full ReviewI am in love with games like this. Even though Bad North has the simplest of concepts, no dialogues, just a little bit of text, it is still highly engaging, replayable, and strategic.It may look too casual for experienced players. I can assure you â€“ it is not. There are things to learn for an efficient playthrough. By choosing a weak strategy early in the game, you condemn yourself for a tough endgame, which you may not complete. You have to assign your commanders carefully and fight for every coin! Battles aren't easy, even when you know all your tactical maneuvers â€“ you still may end up overwhelmed by enemies if you're unlucky. However, it is fun to learn your options. there is this satisfying feeling of being smart when your squads smash those poor bastards left and right despite all odds. You have to know your enemies and abilities. You have to micromanage some fights. Occasionally, you will have to push one of your valued commanders to the brink of death or sacrifice some buildings to gain better chances for survival. Non-obvious solutions may work when everything else fails. That is why in terms of strategy and tactics, this game is nearly perfect (well, for its conceptual simplicity anyway.)The in-game map deserves a separate mention. O my, the map looks gorgeous! You can see the islands' layout, elevation, buildings, unpenetrable walls, and plan your strategy accordingly. When the battle ends, you can even see the rivers of blood where the action took place. I love maps, and this one is pure awesomeness!In conclusion, Bad North is a satisfying experience made with wit and style. It incorporates elements of different genres: tower defense, RTS, simulation of sorts, even roguelike in the spirit of FTL. Fantastic game. A shoutout to Raw Fury for publishing this indie gem.

Fun indie game. Am having a blast playing. Now unless I missed it in my first playthrough of 1hr but it doesnt seem to have a story (not that it really needs one per se but Id love to learn a little of what is going on). If youre a fan of strategy games and dont mind rng maps then you might love it. It gets a 3.5 out 5 from me. Or if you're from the mindset of Buy/Wait 4 Sale/Avoid its a Wait for Sale (or further updates). Updated: Beat the game on normal and currently on Hard for a playthrough. Changed score from "4" to "3.5" and from "Buy" to "Wait for Sale" as well as added the improvements needed. Do I still enjoy the game? Yes, but could be improved upon.Pros:-Easy to learn-Intuitive controls/gameplay-Amusing and pretty graphics and art style-Fun for a quick game (only have 15 mins? then you can play 1 or two islands!)-Replayability (due to rng waves and islands)Cons:-No story-Difficulty spike at the end-No persistent progressionImprovements:-Enemy units seem to be far more diverse while yours are down to sword/shield, spearman/pikeman and archer thats it. (Little more on this later)-Requires more items (as it stands I only saw 3 Hammer (aoe damage and knockback), bomb (aoe damage and knockback) and recruitmant horn (replenishes lost units).-Additionally some light story even if basic and minimlistic.-Persistent progression between playthroughs would be nice for instance maybe you start out with only being able to have 3 commanders per battle to through various runs have up to 5. Similarly squads could start out with max 6 units and be upgraded to 9. -And or split the unit upgrade path between armour and weapon (this could allow the shield/sword units to then also become axe throwers, weaker melee but with a single range attack, or paladins, slow heavy armoured, adding further class depth might I add the enemy already has axe throwers so the code is there)

I've heard some negative criticism and some positives about the game and I really want to voice my opinion on this game because I feel like the devs have something really *REALLY* special here, it's absolutely worth your time even if you may not get a lot of mileage out of it.Bad North is a deliberately paced game broken up in to two segments.The action phase of the game takes place on the many procedurally generated islands in the game, you choose which commanders to bring (this usually boils down to the same 4 commanders you've sunk all your coins in to, unless you're going for a specific achievement) and then ships with various viking troops slowly sail towards the shores. There's a big rock/paper/scissors element going on here where shields counter archers, archers counter unshielded units, and pikes counter... well everything without a bow lol. It's really fun trying to defend all the buildings on each island. It's worth noting, your mission on each island is merely surviving the onslaught of enemy troops. Keeping the buildings in tact is optional, although, you should strive to keep every building standing if you hope to get enough coin to upgrade all your units enough for the late game.After a few islands you'll feel the game is far too easy but then the game begins introducing some scary units and you'll encounter a spike in difficulty which can cause abrupt and frustrating losses. With some clever unit positioning and proper timing of unit replenishment you'll likely find an answer to any situation.The second phase of the game is the overworld/planning stage. Your goal is to move across the overworld map from node to node while the viking horde encroaches on you (if you know FTL this will look very familiar, although much more simplified.) While on this overworld map you can spend the coins your various commanders are holding to upgrade them as you see fit. A lot of the tactics in this game come from these upgrades as certain items and upgrades are very powerful depending on your situation. In this regard the game falls a little flat, there aren't nearly enough interesting options to choose from outside of items (which are also not too varied.)Unclassed units can choose between pikemen, archer, or knight after getting 6 coins (usually after one or two islands in the early game) but after that the options are sparse. There's no more divergence from the classes, each upgrade to class simply results in a better, tougher, version of the unit. Each unit has a special ability, just one, which you can also upgrade to make it stronger. The final aspect of "customization" come from items you find on certain islands. Giving an item to a unit permanently locks it to that unit and gives them a special ability or passive which can then be upgraded with coins.This game is very very unique with a cute aesthetic, the game may have some frustrating moments with difficulty spikes but it's beautifully crafted and worth the price.AVOID this game if you're:-looking for lots of replayability-expecting in-depth customization options for tactics-looking for your next big rogue-like time-sink. You'll likely experience everything the game has to offer in your first victorious run, unless you're personally invested in exploring different team compositions to challenge yourself.AUTO-BUY this game if:-like me, you love exploring new unique styles of gameplay-you're a fan of tactics/strategy games and want something new-you loved games like FTL, Fire Emblem, or Darkest Dungeon (not too similar to FE or FTL and not at all similar to DD, but I think if you fell in love with any of those games this one will also suit your fancy)-a $15USD (17.49CDN) price point for a game you can expect "only 4 hours play time" doesn't sound like a dealbreaker to youThis is a lovingly crafted game, I personally feel that the indie scene is filled with wildly underpriced games to the point where people think they all need to give you dozens of hours of gameplay if they're anything over 5 dollars.This game gets the point across and delivers a great way to kill some time.edit/update: It's been a long time since writing this review, I still totally agree with it except... I did a really bad job of explaining how awesome it is, reading it over so many of my positive points are phrased in lame or undercutting ways...Game good, game UNIQUE AS HECK, game cute.A successful campaign may take a few hours so you might not beat a "run" in a single sitting. I think there's enough difficulty to prevent you from beating the game in one run which I think is a positive for this type of game.I spent a few attempts and finally beat it while using a well rounded team, I tried again on the hardest difficulty and after awhile managed that, I also did runs where I only allowed myself to use archers, as well as another run where I only used pikemen.I think an average player could find 15+ hours of fun in this game while I spent around 70 or so hours digging through all the ideas/challenges I imposed on myself. (I have a lot of afk time in this game)

A rather barebones roguelike that can be completed within a few hours (minimum of 2 final boss kills)Graphics aren't too bad once you get use to them. buy on heavy sale.For completionists there are 2 obnoxious farm achievements, luckily you can see your run seed in the bottom right and use the last 3 digits of each seed to your advantage while refreshing runs for the first level.50 lost souls farm last digits (:344, :346)50 outlaws farm last digits (:142, :342, :346)

Let me just give you a short and juicy reviewPros:*This game has an amazing art style! Everything you see just feels new (which is rare to see in video games now) and everything just fits together perfectly *Fun combat. Big variety of guns and they all have their little perks, making it possible to create different "builds" to get through the game and changing up how you approach enemies Cons:*Taking cover is a big part in this game and it works well, but it feels very sticky. When you're fighting a big boss or have a bunch of guys coming at you, you're rolling and dodging all over the place, but your character will just snap to cover and when you try rolling away it just takes you to a different cover spot or a different direction entirely *Progression feels good in this game, but it has some flaws. This isn't really a con, but it sure isn't a pro. once you die you have to restart from the beginning, which isn't a big surprise considering this is a roguelike. But the game can get very repetitive, they're four chapters in this game and once you die you start from chapter one... every time. Chapters one-three take around an hour each, so imagine you're almost done with the game and you die because your camera wasn't showing the enemy shooting at you, so now you have to go through all those chapters again and again until you get good enough rng to get good weapons and beat it. And yes, i know that you're suppose to die so you can make some permanent upgrades to your character, but no one wants to go through the same levels 20+ times to beat a game. *The camera is by far this games biggest flaw, it does have it's moments when you step into a big room full of enemies and you just see an overhead view of your character fighting away and dodging all the bullets, but this usually isn't the case. Your camera will most likely pan around, not revealing the enemy you're shooting at or sometimes you can't even see yourself! All the other cons are just little annoying things or stuff that didn't work well, but no matter how hard you try you can't like a game if you can't see it!Final thoughts: This game is a fun experience, it has some replayability but if you've already beaten the game you're probably already worn out of the levels. I would NOT RECOMMEND to buy this at FULL PRICE, but if you find a good deal on it it can be a lot of fun. This game feels like it has all the building blocks made but just wasn't put together correctly. It has good mechanics, cool gun ideas, bosses and different areas. But I feel like the movement and actually playing it is just a pain. I give this an official Gluurb review of 7/10

Wanted to like it, because the atmosphere was unique and looked like it would be shaping up for an excellent story. I can look past the weird game controls, such as insisting on hugging cover in an empty room, melee barely working, etc but the game is entirely too buggy. In three hours of play I've had to restart and lose progress because a level spawned the exit behind a door I don't have the ability to open yet. Next run an enemy spawned under a ladder and clipped me through a wall until the game suffered a hard crash. If it wasn't a roguelike, wouldn't be a big deal, but that was about two wasted hours in three hours of game play. No excuse after all this time to not have catastrophic bugs ironed out.

West of Dead is a rogue-like isometric western shooting game, where you have to outgun your enemies in the unknown procedurally generated hunting grounds. I have not played many rogue-likes before, but I honestly enjoyed playing this one. I love the artwork the most. It is very nice to look at. The soundtrack is good as well. The story is pretty average, and I have mixed feelings about the gameplay. Sometimes, you just die because your character does not want to follow your controls, and it gets a bit frustrating. Overall 7/10.

I personally love this game, but it's a difficult sell in some regards.It's the kind of game indie games have needed since FTL: something that takes the mechanics of a beloved game genre, encases them in a creative and appealing setting with a killer soundtrack, and provides a familiar but unique experience to players across generations. It's got a great gameplay loop, satisfying kills, and plenty of challenge. However, it's let down by some odd (but rare for me, anyway) bugs, too many useless "dead-end" weapon unlocks, and a bad difficulty curve caused mostly by overinflated health values.West of Dead starts out slowly, since the player is supposed to fight enemies and cash in "sin" (unlock points) for more unlocks (weapons, usable items, passive trinkets, and gameplay features). Players are supposed to fight, acquire and cash in sin, then eventually die. This is all fine and good, until the player starts unlocking more weapons.My first gripe with the game is that the more the player unlocks, the worse the equipment RNG gets for subsequent runs. I remember getting pretty far in the beta and getting used to the gameplay loop to the point where when the game released, I breezed through the first three levels without a second glance. Eventually I died at the Farm for my first death, and cashed in my sin. I was surprised at how many cool-sounding weapons there were that were possibly available to me. For subsequent runs, I wasn't afraid of dying after cashing in a level or three of sin: it was all just a step closer to cooler guns and items to use. Well... that's not how it went. Here are some examples of in-game buyer's remorse that continue to haunt me: Escalator.Selling point is that consecutive shots cause crits, but it's only got 3 rounds and a lengthy charging time for accuracy. The weapon's usefulness drops off harder than most when progressing from level to level even if the player is boosting their perception (gun damage) stat for the given run. Traitor.Outside of rock golems, enemies don't stay stunned long enough for the ability of the weapon to be meaningful (crits when hitting an enemy in the back). Last Stand. Exact same problem as the Escalator.  Longshot. Shotgun with low base damage that has "extended" range. Another weapon that falls off hard like the Escalator. Jester.After rolling, the user's next shot is a critical hit. Issue is, the roll doesn't always guarantee a critical for a number of reasons: sometimes it's just bugged and doesn't remember that the player rolled, other times the player rolls and fires too late and gets a normal shot.This list could easily go on, and it annoys me that it could. I've often found myself in this position with games like this, going "yes, not every gun has to be good, but not as bad as this". It goes hand-in-hand with my next gripe: the health (and damage) scaling of opponents is absolutely insane and there aren't enough stat boosts and good weapon drops in the game to keep up. I've gotten to the Church and Churchyard several times with high stats across the board, and it still isn't enough to make it through. What might've been fine in the Town quickly becomes borderline useless. No one I know has been able to actually make it past the Church, and looking at the achievement stats for West of Dead, only 1.4% of the playerbase have beaten the Canyon. 1.3% have been able to beat the Church. Obviously practice makes perfect and I'll probably beat the Church by hitting that level enough and preparing myself for every dumb encounter I could possibly have there, but the investment for doing so is way too much, in my opinion.With the bugs they've had and the gameplay mechanic issues I've outlined, Arcade Fury probably should have taken it into Early Access. However, to their credit, they've just added a lot of good quality of life features and the ability to aim at opponents hidden in the dark manually on July 1st, 2020. I really hope Arcade Fury keeps working at West of Dead so this game can truly shine as a recommendation, but I like the game enough to still recommend buying it. It definitely has the sauce.

West of Dead is one of those typical games that had a rough start, but over time grew to become what the devs have initially planned it to be - from its buggy beginnings, lack of KB & M support and being practically devoid of content, in a period of one year it managed to arrive at the point where I would consider it to be a pretty challenging game with a well-narrated story full of mystery - albeit with its own design-flaws which mare the experience quite a bit.The pros of the game are the setting, visuals, general gameplay and music: the Weird West sort-of otherworldly experience is a perfect match for rogue-lite gameplay, the player traversing the Purgatory over and over again trying to figure who he is and what's he up against. Visuals are well done, evocative of Mignola's style of stark contrasts and deep, pitch-black shadows, and the music is somber, reflects what is happening on the screen, and appropriate for this setting (but it gets quite repetitive after 10 hours or so). Overall, the elements for what I consider to be a "pretty good" game are all there, but...The cons that are the apparent lack of content and insane grind outweigh the good parts - I know this is a roguelite and that the devs want you to play the game over and over again ad nauseum, but what IS in the game content-wise is SEVERELY lacking, and the unlockables are progressing at a snails pace. I managed to finish the entire game in 8-9 hours, and after continuing to pursue grindy achievements to 100% the game (i.e. a full 17 hours (!) later), I can tel you that I cannot recommend this game. First off, the Good Soul achievement relies too much on RNG - you can play through the ENTIRE game and encounter maybe one lost soul (or none at all), which is unacceptable since you need 50 (!?) for the 3rd rank of that achievement. As a matter of fact, getting to those 50 souls took me 17 hours, nearly double the amount I needed to beat the game fully.Next is the weapon unlock system - you basically have to not only have luck in order to make those remnants (which unlock items and weapons) drop at all, but you must then power them up with in-game currency called "sins" that may or may not drop from enemies you kill. And considering that there are quite a few unlock with 30+ cost, and some at 50+ sins requirement (and gaining around 12 sins per map), well.... it is a very lame unlock system, to be frank.Thirdly, the devs could have capitalized big-time on adding more game related achievements that actually make sense and go hand-in-hand with their design logic to extend play time - like "Collect all items in the game" or "Beat the game on Deputy/Gunslinger/Sheriff/Marshal difficulty" or "Beat the game without refilling your HP flask" etc., yet the devs have failed to do so. Having an achievement to drive you to beat the game on harder difficulty (I completed the game on Gunslinger, mind you) would alleviate a LOT of problems with grind I listed above, because in trying to surmount the challenge would the grindy parts balance themselves (as in you would get to those required numbers of saved souls and dead outlaws more naturally, without having to resort to fulfilling them artificially).Since the devs have gone radio-silent since 12 May 2021 (their last game update), I have little hope of them polishing this game to reflect the cons I listed in this review - really sad, since I find that the game could really be something else than just a quick 9-hour affair, the rest being just achievement hunting for completionist sake (and not a pleasant one at that). Getting West of Dead on a deep, DEEP sale would be my final recommendation ($9 or less, to reflect what you actually get for your money). There was never a game that made me feel like I was in real-life Purgatory, doing the same grindy chore over and over until I earned my way to Heaven (or Hell, since I feel like a rotten corpse grinding this achievemenbt stuff).

-Very short game, when you know what to do it can be finished in less than 1.5 hours.-Pretty nice music and post fight sound effects.-Have a ton of unlockables but some of them don't really feel useful.-In some rare occasions, some objects hanging on the top can block your camera sometimes.-2 grindy achievements.

I'll start this review by saying WoD could be a really great game. The good things are very good, and the bad things are (to me) confusing choices the devs made, that look like the game was never properly finished / tested. For starters, the game was released full of bugs, and even after a lot of patches, some still make an appearance once in a while.The game's graphics make it look like a comic book, and I personally love that.The voices are also great, and Ron was a great choice for the part.The sounds FX and music have its moments of brilliance - I could do without some of the door breaking samples.The game's most appropriate tag is indeed action roguelike, but don't expect a huge amount of action, and it's a very short rogue to be honest. The game can be finished from chapter 1 to chapter 4, in about 3 hours (once you master the mechanics). That's 2 runs from start to finish, maybe 3 in order to pick up some extra "runes". The game flow is quite balanced, and feels smooth as you go from room to room, taking a few enemies at a time, and exploring a bit more of the map (even if there isn't really much to explore). Some players could find it slow though. This is not a shoot'em'up, and even if you can get weapons that discharge a lot of bullets (like revolvers), it just doesn't pay off when you can have the same damage (or more) with two shots from a shotgun. Unfortunately, after a while it does get a bit repetitive, as it stops being challenging, and here comes the weird part - unlike other roguelike games, where it gets easier the more runs you make and items you unlock, WoD's inventory is mostly made of redundant items. Most of the time, unlocking a new weapon ends up making the game harder for you.The basic weapons that are already unlocked from the start - double barrel shotgun and double barrel pistol - are good enough, and in comparison, better than most of the other stuff you unlock: so once again, unlocking new (worse) items and weapons will make the game harder.My advice is to unlock the health flasks, shield, lantern, stay with the defender charm, and you may discard everything else.To make it "better" (not), in order to unlock these items you use "Sin" - Sin is dropped randomly when killing enemies (but each level has a max sin amount you can pick up). You then spend that Sin gradually to unlock new items. So to make it quick, Sin is scarce, and a lot of items have an excessive Sin cost - meaning, you may accumulate a lot of sin from a lot of runs to unlock a certain weapon, and after getting it realize that the weapon is crap, unbalanced, low damage, or has some other downsides that just make it unworthy, but now it will pop up occasionally on your runs - congrats: you just made it harder on yourself.So, do I still recommend it? Yeah... this is still a good game, but it comes with some disappointments for me. It has some interesting mechanics and ideas that may keep the player entertained for a few hours, but once you understand how the enemies work and finish the game, there just isn't any incentive to continue playing - and I'm stating this after having spent over 100 hours on it (and closely the same amount of the Betas).There's a lot of potential for greatness, but the great things on this game set up the bar at a level the rest of the game just fails to reach.

Do you like the Binding of Isaac? Would you be OK replacing Isaac's bullet hell dungeon with cover-based shooting? Would you be OK replacing Isaac's cartoon purgatory with a wild-west purgatory? Would you be OK replacing Isaac's 45 enemies and 43 bosses with 19 enemies and 3 bosses? Can you tolerate a 2-weapon looter shooter system where you guns get weaker every level if you don't swap them out with other random guns? Can you tolerate a cover-based shooting system that is fundamentally buggy, often simply does not work, and will never be patched? If you answered yes to all of the above, West of Dead may be for you. Buy it on sale for $2.

I absolutely recommend this game. Be warned, it is a real test of how much information you are able to filter out. It'll take a good number of runs before that aspect, along with the dexterity/reflexes needed, start to click. Once that clicks, it's a phenomenal blend of genres that you'd never think would work together.A few specific notes: The graphics are wonderfully charming. You can tell a lot of time was spent on every little character, crop, enemy, and biome. The music is unique and every track is excellent. Not necessarily in a "listen on your own time" sort of way, but perfect for every situation they play.  The different characters allow for starting with different buffs to fit your playstyle. Honestly play the coffee guy for a long time (makes the entire game faster) and then go back to a normal character. You'll be able to dodge literally everything. The game starts with no permanent buffs available, they must be unlocked through exploration. Trust me when I say there are a lot more progression unlockables to find than you expect.  It's hard. Not impossibly so, but it'll definitely challenge you. The game scales difficulty on a 10-year selection. You start on Year 1, and every year you beat you allows you to try the next one (That's Year 2 for those keeping track at home). Of course later years are more rewarding at the cost of being harder. Enemies shoot more bullets, there are more of them, enemies that didn't used to shoot now shoot, less health, etc. You know. How games work.Some things early on that might seem discouraging and tips/encouragement:  I can't farm and fight at the same time: This is probably the hardest thing to get used to. My main recommendation is: don't! (mostly). At night, let fighting be your main focus and only plant if you absolutely have to. Also, in the options there's a checkbox for auto-shooting while farming. Turn it on, it's absolutely worth it. While plowing, weeding, or planting the gun will shoot at the nearest target. Try to keep planting to day (watch out for the god-awful moles), between enemy waves, or just before the end of the day.   I can't make any money/can't take the time to farm/can't get stronger/etc: The second hardest thing (maybe tied) is learning what to prioritize. I've found that prioritizing running away from the farm and fighting is more beneficial than tending your farm yourself. I even go as far as not planting anything the first day, just running around the biomes the entire first day and night, fighting and getting seeds/upgrade. Find yourself some animals (prioritize cows for watering) to automate the farm a bit, and get a bunch of great buffs.  I can't seem to get any further/better: I would take a few runs, maybe even a dozen, just running around, fighting, and ignoring the farming entirely. Get used to the bullet patterns, find and learn about what upgrades are out there. You'll run into a little trouble going beyond the first left and right biomes with the pea shooter, but if you're doing well and have build up a lot of upgrades, introduce the farming again, a least a little, to get some money for more weapons. The actual roguelike element of permanent upgrades has to be unlocked by finding things in the surrounding biomes, so focusing on just that for a few runs can get things moving.And at that, it's nearly 2am, I just had the best run to date, and I've got work in the morning. And it's all Atomicrops' fault.
