Hold on to your knickers, people, cause the BAD is a lot. However, I would be so bold as to urge you to look at the BAD subjectively. Please decide for youself what's actually good or bad for you.1. Steep learning curve. The game is easy to pick up but expects you to play it for a good amount of time in order to learn its quirks.2. The game is frustratingly punishing. Winning a mission is not always a factor of character build and player skill.3. If you are the type to get easily aggravated, frustrated, or flat out pissed off at what happens on the screen, this game is not for you.4. Your adventurers forget everything they did in the previous dungeon and start at level 1 every single time... But that's not all: they also completely lose the gear hey got from the last run. Now I, personally, think that they just get so happy for being alive in such a punishing game, that they get so horribly drunk in the city tavern and pass out and someone steals their gear and returns them to first grade. I blame it on the Ivory League. Them freaking cheaters.5. RNG can screw you big time. It can even lose you a mission. This may happen so often, that it will force you to ragequit or dub the game as an downright infair, so much so that you might shelf it.6. You will ragequit many a time, especially if you have a short fuse.7. The game doesn't present much in terms of graphical and aesthetical fidelity for our modern age.8. There are no RPG elements of any sort that many people would expect from this type of game.9. There is no multiplayer. No co-op or LAN or anything.10.  Difficulty ramps up very quickly. If you don't know the quirks of the game, you might find yourself over your head in no time, which results in lost missions.11. Some classes are need revamping and balancing, as they are better than the others.12. So easy to lose a fight and the mission as a result.And now, the conclusion. I will make it very plain and simple.You should buy the game if:- you're a casual gamer- you like in-game humor that puts a smile on your face- you can accept the game for what it is - a parody to dungeoneering- you like games that you can play for a bit every now and then when you feel like, but still return to them and have just as much fun as before- you like jokes, jabs and pokes to various cultures and franchises- you like card games- you like skill based games- you like challenges- you like ironman games- you like experimenting- you don't care about losing, but enjoy learning from experience and adapting as a resultYou shouldn't buy the game if:- you are a very serious gamer that expects a huge value from a purchase- you have a short fuse and get frustrated easily- you dislike the random number generator- you ragequit a lot- you expect a game that will get you glued to the pc for days on end- you dislike games with a huge learning curve- you don't like seeing your minions die for the greater purposeSo why would I recommend the game?I would recommend it because it is the right game for me. I love games that have lots of humor, don't take themselves seriously and put a smile on my face. This one did it - even as I was losing horribly. It never made me feel bad for it and always had this jovial feeling of letting me fool around with it - be it with additional classes, options, and avenues of advancement. I was enjoying myself regardless of what was happening, and I believe this to be one of the most important factors in a game.

First impressions of the game were great.  I was excited to play, everything was funny and great to discover - and then it clicked: I already saw everything the game had to offer.The game mechanics are the same from start to finish.Do quests, use money to upgrade guild hall, get new equipment, do quests, use money to upgrade guild hall, get new equipment... Sure, this is every RPG-style game, is it not?  There's always some *reason* why you're doing this, though.  Some end goal.  Something to motivate you to continue.  Some change in game mechanics.  Here?  Nothing.  It's really a one-trick pony.  Do quest, get new equipment, do quest, get new equipment, rinse and repeat.I found myself bored within hours.  There was nothing that captivated me, here.  The narrator starts to grate on you singing the same tune at every significant event.  You feel no love for your heroes, they die, and are instantly replaced.  There's no benefit to keeping them alive longer.Bottom line, Guild of Dungeoneering is extremely lacklustre.Guild of Dungeoneering feels like it should have been a mobile game, where you would play a dungeon and come back in a few hours time when your heroes are ready to go again.  There's so little meat and potatoes to the game, I'm disappointed.

Guild of Dungeoneering is a game that should be good but isn't. It has a great visual style, interesting turn based combat and some complexity and depth to the game. But ultimately any fun that could be had in the game is utterly ruined by the unforgiving and more importantly uninteresting difficulty. You build a couple of upgrades, send a person into a dungeon, get an unlucky hand draw (or the enemy gets a great hand draw) two or three monsters in, die, repeat ad infinitum.Essentially you end up endlessly sending people to their deaths for 10-20 gold in the hopes of buying a better hero for a 10% increased chance not to get ruined by random card draws in the same dungeon. I haven't seen any real way to work around this system. Card Draw? Doesn't matter every deck starts with 5-10 unremovable terrible cards that you can get in a row and lose the dungeon. Damage? Eventually a monster will get 5 or so 2+ damage turns and kill you, Specialisation? Can't do, physical block works on only physical enemies, magical likewise. Get used to your warriors wielding spell books and your mages wielding shields and armour to make up for the glaring flaws in their base decks.You'll enter the same dungeon many times waiting for a good set of gear to randomnly drop, a series of unlucky enemy card draws from every monster you fight and enough gold from the corpses of previous heroes to have appropriate upgrades in town to win. It ends up being insanely tedious. I swear I've played this game far longer than two hours, it felt endless monotony each time I played.I wouldn't recommend this game to anyone, the balance and feel of the game is utterly ruined to the spammy, meaningless manner in which you throw away lives into dungeons and how overtuned the game feels to play. This fact is worsened by the meaningless, replaceable feeling of heroes, as you get a new one as soon as one dies and the complete lack of distinguishing features for a hero. They lack customised looks, RPG mechanics such as levels or talents, experience or power gain from surviving the horribly overtuned dungeons.In the end because everyone and everything was so meaningless and replaceable in the game, the game itself became replaceable. Essentially, whilst it has all the style and aesthetics of a cool, fun game it ultimately lacks a soul or any reason to keep playing it.

Could have been excellent but instead is just okay. Main reasons why it gets the downgrade is because:1) Too many mechanics where the outcome of a situation is entirely out of the players control. Some examples such as unable to draw the correct room cards to advance to an objective before a round timer, or a awful draw set on the first battle of a dungeon causing an near insta-loss.2) When characters die (which they will often) the grind to rebuild a well traited unit is way too long and unrewarding. Instead you'll find yourself just throwing untrained units at the challenge until you finally get some decent RNG.3) A lot of the early game unit classes don't seem very useful as there default card set is under powered compared to class unlocks later.If you want a casual time waster this game is okay for that but if you are looking for a serious game I would look elsewhere.
Product received for free

This game came out of nowhere and scratched the itch I been so desperately wanting as someone who loves card games and rpgs. The concept of wanting to build your deck and go against other people and obtain cards to slowly tune it and make it stronger is the experience I been craving for and it nails it on the head. I been scouring for these type of games, but most of these titles are either old Yugioh games or recent titles that are likely to never be imported to the west. Card Battler RPG feels extremely underrated. For this title to pop out of nowhere and exceed my expectations as a single player experience has land it right into my favorite games of all time list. I want to personally thank the Devs for creating this game that has finally satisfied my childhood.This game really deserves more attention.

If you fall in to one or both of these categories you should give this game a shot.A) Love card battlers but don't want to pay for CCG/TCGsB) Traded or played with trading cards in elementary schoolImmediately hit me in the 4th grade nostalgia when I was running around the playground trading cards with every kid I could find while trying to hide from teachers.A+++ on theme and concept.

This game could have been AMAZING but has some design and balance shortcomings. I'll list them briefly then go into more detail below.1) No way to collect all the cards or undo certain permanent changes2) No real post game or new game+ to try out different deck types. Unskippable cutscenes ruin the thought of replaying the game.3) Some balance shortcomings can make a couple parts almost impossible in some cases, this game is otherwise extremely easy.I still had fun with this game and not a lot of people make games like this anymore. The story and writing is charming and the art grew on me. The complaints only hurt so hard because the rest of the game shows so much promise. I still had fun with my 14ish hours of it but I wouldn't recommend paying full price unless you really love these types of games.I'll elaborate my complaints here for those curious:1 and 2) My biggest complaint is they made a 'collectible card game' with no was to collect all the cards you want. Further more, as you go you'll get several choices to do rule changes like "Minions with the defender keyword cost 1 less" or "minions with ambush have 2 more health", there is no way to undo these changes are go back and choose different options so you're really stuck making a decision on what type of deck to play early on and sticking with that through the whole game. There's no way to try pivoting to a different deck type half way through and having it being even a fraction as good. These game desperately needs a post game option to continue collecting cards and stickers and options to undo/change the rules you've unlocked. They added a half-ass postgame with just a few more opponents to challenge, but they unlock nothing and theres no way to get more cards than what you collected in the main game.3) Lastly is the balance issues. The AI is pretty dumb and 95% of the game is super easy, but the game can still be challenging at some points due mostly do my first complaint. You can make rule changes early on that make some mandatory later fights almost impossible. For example, every time I got a rule change I chose the option to nerf the decks that gave me the hardest time - so making defender and lethal type minions weaker. At one point late in the game I was forced to play another kids deck against a strong opponent and that kid happen to only have defender and lethal cards which I ended up making completely useless with my rule changes. There's no warning the game will throw these curveballs at you and I would have to redo 10+ hours of work if I wanted to reload a save before those changes. I ended up fighting the enemy about 20 times and watching the same unskippable cutscene 20 times before I got the right combination of perfect luck and bad luck for the AI to win and proceed. There's some other 'challenge' matches that can be difficult if you don't know they're coming. Some will require you to only play cards without certain keywords or without any stickers - but if you already put stickers on all your cards before hand or added keywords to most of your cards there's no way to undo this and you can be stuck without a functional deck to use for the challenge. Again, 95% of the game is extremely easy with a few spikes of difficulty that feel more like bad balancing than actual challenges.

This game is good for what it is, but it's not what I wanted. The card combat is a distant second priority to the questing and storyline.+ A campaign full of interesting, branching quests+ An authentically juvenile personality+ A trading economy, house-rules, and other elements simulating the fun of a schoolyard game- Slow-paced- The game uses Hearthstone as a base, and it's a pretty poor Hearthclone- Ugly (on purpose) character designs that don't evoke the time period or actual multimedia franchises as much as they could, which kinda takes me outta the setting- Having to deal with all the schoolyard economy stuff when the card game isn't that good kinda mutes the joy of it

At first, I wanted to write a short thank you note to the developers because as a lifelong wheelchair user and a geeky girl, the protagonist of this game and her story made me very happy. But the disability representation in Cardpocalypse is so perfect that instead, Iâ€™ll write an article about it on my blog.

I like the look of the game and 'kids playing' aspect. The card game itself is also neet with some card abilties that are quite interesting. The Mega mechanic and your champion always being able to attack are unique ideas. What is lacking is the AI. It is Hearthstone levels of dumb. They often attack enemy minions without killing them, or attack with the champion first taking extra damage when the minion would have already killed it etc. I am only at day 2 so I don't know if the AI gets better later on in the game or if it is always this bad. In any case there should be better AI available from the start with an additional difficulty setting (the challenge mode is a joke and I am surprised there is an even easier setting).

You can permanently lose cards and the game forces you to make blind choices on gaining new cards. You have no idea what cards/champions will be offered in the future so you have no idea how useful each of the offered cards will be in the long run. Additionally, almost all of the "quests" just have you walking back and forth across the map talking to people and making pointless dialogue choices. The art style is fairly unique, but instead of slowly building an deck and strategy throughout the game you are forced to randomly choose cards with the blind hope that you aren't accidentally passing over an essential card.

FOR MORE REVIEWS ABOUT CARD GAMES, CHECK OUT OUR CURATOR PAGE: CARD GAME KING     What is this game about?  Cardpocalypse puts you in shoes of Jess, a kid from school that learns a new card game that everyone at the school plays (cool kids anyway). The game tries to set the 90s mode vibes, and at times succeeds in that. However, the actual card game is rather one dimensional and can get repetitive very quickly.The card game's goal it to drop your opponent to 0 with two types of cards minions and "trap" cards. Later in the game you unlock the ability to upgrade cards giving them new keywords which opens up new possibilities, at least a bit. Even later, and I would say too late, the game lets you change the game rules sometimes very drastically. This is the coolest mechanic, but I was already exhausted by the time Iâ€™ve reached it.The worst part of the game is the AI which is no less than ABYSMAL. While it's understandable that AI can't be good as a human in a card game this level of bad is entirely unacceptable and it's just lazy programming. To give an example, you have a 1/2 minion and the enemy has a hero with 1 attack and minion with 2/2. Instead of attacking with the minion first, the AI choses to attack with the hero losing one health as the ally minion attacks back. THEN it overkills it with the 2/2 minion. In the same manner sometimes it needlessly sacrifices minions by getting the order of attacks wrong, and sometimes instead of attacking your hero and winning the game it attacks your minions. For deckbuilding, you have 4 different factions but honestly, aside from completing challenges, you won't need to play more than one, which ends your deckbuilding quite early as you will be just replacing a few cards here and there. Getting new cards is done through quests and the trading gimmick. The trading gimmick is a bit frustrating as you need to say goodbye to some of your cards to get new ones. With this the game pushes you even harder to stick to one faction, which does not help with the repetitiveness. The quests followed by elementary school dialogue, while not entirely mindless, do boil down to three things: go fetch something, choose a dialogue option and battle.Finally the story is ok and the dialogue is fine, if you have in mind the the main protagonist is a kid in an elementary school. The positive  + Rules of the game change is a cool mechanic. (too) Late in the game you get to pick how the rules of the game change. This is a very cool gimmick that should have been introduced way earlier. Sadly, once youâ€™re done with the main quest, there is no incentive to replay the game and try the other rules.+ Trash talk. I don't know why, but I find the trash talk that kids do before each battle kinda amusing.+ Soundtrack is pretty good. Gotta love them riffs.The neutral *  Hover over for card details. Mild annoyance as it comes with a delay or not at all. I don't know why it wasnâ€™t assigned to a right click as usual or have it appear more consistently.* Single deck. The game nudges you into playing with a single faction the entire time. The only exception are the challenges that are easier or harder depending on the faction you play (hope you haven't traded all the other faction cards).* Quests are kinda boring. The negative  -  AI is the worst I've seen in a card game. It's a simple card game and I don't expect it to be at a level of a capable human, but I do expect it to understand basic card play and attack order. Of course, when the AI is bad you have to balance it out by giving opponents fully upgraded cards.- Too pricey. I don't usually comment on a price but at 24$ this is simply far above what this game is worth. Get it on sale of at least 50%.- EDIT: The sidequests have to many steps. I had to go back and add this point A good sidequest formula is that you go somewhere and then some unexpected twist happens. However, in this game some side quests will have you wander from person to person and hoping this is the last "twist" or "extra thing" you need to do.Conclusion:  It's an OK game that likely wonâ€™t â€œwowâ€ many card game fans, but itâ€™s worthy of a casual distraction. The only innovation it had was not used to its fullest potential. Careful recommendation as long as you know what you're getting yourself into.

Cardpocalypse is a deckbuilding adventure in which you play a kid arriving at a new school were everyone plays that one card game and watches the accompanying cartoon.The charming cast of children is reminiscent of Costume Quest, but the sinister story and card battling are all it's own.Highly recommended for people who enjoy cute protagonists, a good story, and deck building.

It is beautiful to look at. It's extremely atmospheric, the sound design is great, the voice acting is great. The game mechanics are very simple, and clean. The gameplay and game design of this game are amazing. The plot, however, is so terrible that I cannot in good conscience recommend this game. And I don't mean it in the wink-wink-nudge-nudge way, I mean I truly do not think this studio deserves money from this product, and I regret supporting them by purchasing it myself. Watch a let's play of this or look at screenshots if you want to experience this game, do not buy. Spoilers below:-----I read the reviews and had the vague ending of the game spoiled to me pre-purchase. I got the game thinking 'ok, it can't be THAT bad, these people are being dramatic'. It is. It is that bad. And the issue isn't even from the fact that the main character's dad is a pedophile who preyed on an extremely isolated girl he was tutoring, or that Rachel was killed by the mother, or even that Irving would go to the hotel to work with the pedophile who knocked up his sister to try to solve her murder. The problem is that by the end of the game, the story is trying its hardest to paint the mother as the exclusive bad guy, and the father as a misunderstood, desperate man who's stayed tragically in love with Rachel since her murder. And! By the end of the game everyone is dead, including Irving (by suicide), and the game gives you the choice to have the main character kill herself too. You also have the choice NOT to kill her, but if you don't have her commit suicide, she instead decides to spend the rest of her life in the falling-apart, rotting hotel trying to return the hotel to its glory days and reunite with her "mommy and daddy". So, ok, besides the fact that this game doesn't treat the idea of suicide tastefully or respectfully AT ALL (rather, it's used exclusively as a plot device that 'crazy people' turn to as an escape AND as a punishment), WHY did the game choose to make the father sympathetic? By the end of the game, we are told that the mother is desperate to be loved and needed, so in a jealous rage she killed the pregnant teenager that her pedophilic husband r*ped and knocked up (keep in mind that since the main character says the affair lasted a year, Rachel was actually 15 when this all started). Everyone talks about how perfect and angelic Rachel was, and how the father's love for her (and her alleged returned love) was pure and simple (I mean....not simple enough, apparently, since he r*ped her), and how the main character didn't need to be jealous of Rachel because her father's soul "was big enough to love both you and Rachel." I mean I HOPE not, because the 'love' he had for Rachel was sexual. And Rachel and the main character were very much the same age. The affair, the grooming, the mother killing Rachel or, hell, the father killing Rachel and the mother helping hide the body even, those would have been fine plotlines. That would have made a good, tragic story, where Rachel alone (and to an extent the main character) was the victim. Irving getting unhinged and helping the father try to solve the murder, and being ok with all the creepy things the father did, that could be ok too. It's the fact that the story tries so hard to make the father into a tragic victim who did nothing wrong, the fact that by the end of the story the main character is calling him "Daddy" again and longing for his affection and comfort again, that's so absurd. And the fact that the main character's fate is either 'commit suicide to be with everyone in heaven', or 'presumably live out the rest of her days talking to herself and wandering the decrepit hotel like the Hollywood version of a crazy person' is an insult to her, the player, and real life people who are victims of parental/guardian/mentor abuse. Not to be petty, but it's also straight up bad story-telling. We have NO hints throughout the game that the main character is anything but blunt, pragmatic, and level-headed. At MOST she thinks there MIGHT be a ghost in the hotel, but even then, you can chose answers agreeing that it's probably the wind. You're telling me that over the course of a week her response to finding out her mother killed a teenager that she was ALREADY FURIOUS at her father for allegedly driving to suicide is to become unhinged herself, and NOT to get angry again and want to burn the hotel to the ground? That she goes full Shining, immediately? Ok.

I don't usually do reviews, but after suffering through this mess with my fiance I felt obligated to so. I'm only going to hit a few of the big points as I'm sure other reviewers have touched on all of them already. I'm really only here to add my downvote to the pile and hopefully help any likeminded players avoid this entirely.There will be major spoilers in this review, continue at your own behest with that knowledge if you have not already played or watched the game.I'll start with what I thought was actually done well, which honestly is really only the opening sequence and the general design of the hotel the game takes place in. -- I surpassed the word limit and had to cut this part out. The hotel was cool, basically. Sorry if things look a little disjointed as a result, there were more cuts.--So to get right into the bad playing off that last point, the hotel actually kinda sucks once you're allowed to explore it. There are a few places you are barred entry to until pre-defined game sequences, but for the most part the entire game takes place between a small handful of rooms that you'll be hobbling back and forth to to further the plot (and I mean hobbling, the base walking speed is a slow crawl and the 'run' speed is almost a casual walking pace). Exploration is not encouraged nor is it rewarded. The game *explicitly* tells you at the start, that careful observation was required to find 'the truth' but this is a blatant lie.Nothing you can look at that isn't your specific goal that triggers the next bit of exposition to be puked at you will ever matter. You can pick up objects to rotate them around and get a better look at them, but this mechanic is an afterthought, there is no point in the game where you glean any additional information or learn any fun secrets by examining items that you couldn't have gotten just from looking at it.To top it off, you are railroaded into following the plot point for point at the exact slow pace the game wants you to do so, finding the little hatches that access crawl spaces, or other important items or locations early just means you know exactly where they are when the game deigns to allow you to touch them. (A particular frustration for me was during my playthrough when you get a very obvious screwdriver hanging half off a shelf all the way in the basement, which gets a little label when you look at it, but you cannot pick it up until it's needed for the plot later, which entails a long walk down to it.--What little exploration there is, is not touched on by the characters, even the spooky candles in the bathroom.--There's an entire floor plan, including a handheld map of each floor you can examine at any time, for 3 floors plus the basement of the hotel, and you can see on your handheld map as well as the big maps on the walls that only a few rooms will ever be enterable during the game, as they are the only ones with an internal floor plan. Despite this, your character mentions on her first day that you cannot get into the rest of the hotel rooms to inspect them (the premise of being there in the first place) without the key. You will never be asked to search for this key, nor is there one for you to find. So outside of the few rooms open to you and the direct plot, you will explore a lot of hallways and not much else.This ties into a major frustration I had in the early game, --you don't investigate a damn thing, every piece of plot information is spewed at you through the character Irving, on your cell phone, who is a creepy and increasingly unhinged character responsible for manipulating the entire game. This includes your arrival time, trapping you in the hotel, deliberately scaring you and leaving 'clues' around for you to find. Despite this, Irving is meant to be portrayed as a charming voice of reason for your character. Your own character mind you, has her entire personality from the opening sequence dropped, then cycling back and forth seemingly at random and suddenly being perfectly cool with the Irving character, who you actively dislike on day one.All of the development that leads to that is implied to happen during the random time jumps at the end of every 'day', where you will complete your set objective and then suddenly black screened to another random point of the hotel an undetermined amount of time later for the next objective. To make this even worse, the only kinda cool potential for 'investigation' that happens during the game is handled FOR you, in favor of asking Irving his thoughts on the characters discoveries. a set of clues --you get jump cut to already laid out.-- Larger spoilers ahead.All of this would be somewhat forgivable, except the increasingly off the wall and disgusting plot that we're being forced into, which seems to start off on the right foot, devolves into Irving berating your character (and her perfectly accepting of this insane nonsense) as well as the entire plot building up how great your character's father was, a pedophile/rapist who impregnated Rachel Foster, his 16 year old student with developmental disabilities, who was possibly kept (likely with the knowledge of her own father, the Reverend or whatever) in a secret underground prison of a room just beneath the chuch, with crayon drawings of windows and furniture and whatnot. Your father is played up to be the tragic hero of this entire story, with everyone else being in the wrong for their reaction to his disgusting behavior. Irving, now revealed as Rachel's younger brother, even angrily tells you at one point "Your father was a *very* special man, and he had love enough for BOTH of you.--" Something that your character, instead of rightfully being wigged out by, actually apologizes to Irving for.You will then find out that your mother, who ran away with you after the discovery of the fathers affair years before the game began, actually murdered Rachel and dumped the body herself. Subsequently painted as the only character in the wrong in this plot. After this point, Irving goes out to kill himself in the winter storm while the character, now inexplicably attached to him, begs and pleads for him not to do it. The next jump cut scene ends with you back in your car in the garage, with a tube from the muffler to your window, waiting to kill yourself. You get a call from the lawyer who was going to help you sell the hotel, tell him you're staying forever and then go into an unhinged monologue talking to your 'daddy', mom, Rachel and Irving about how you'll all be together again.It's not clear here as there is no engine noise, but the car is already on and while you *can* turn it off to not let the main character kill herself, this is evidently not the option the dev wanted, as there is only an achievement for letting her kill herself. That's their intended ending. The last 30-40 minutes or so of the game (the final sequence or two) is just a huge mess of excuses being made for a pedophile and a complete abandonment of any logic or reason, you even visit the disgusting shrine to Rachel in your father's old 'man cave' in the attic. Included are several pencil drawings of, presumably, Rachel in sexual poses, a 'bed' made up of blankets and cushions on the floor. The entire thing is an unintentional nightmare for a love the game is trying to sell you between your 38-40 year old father and his again, 16 year old *student* with disabilities.I honestly don't know what the devs were thinking. They had an amazing opportunity and a strong opening to approach what is inherently a deluge of sensitive topics and they just bait and switch you into getting punched in the gut and laughed at.All in all, this game is not a great exploration walking sim, not a great investigation game, not a worthwhile story and altogether a disappointment. It doesn't do anything much better than other games of the genre and it does a lot much worse.

Up til the end I found the game pretty decent, bugs and all. But then the ending came and went... whooa not how I expected. Which usually don't make a game bad but in since the "unexpected" part was excusing and romanticizing p3doph!l!a and su!c!de it just made the whole experience feel all kinds of bad.

Not only poorly executed and poorly written, but attempts to show sensitive subject matter with a *new interesting* perspective that results in only in glorifying actions and perspectives that should never be entertained or encouraged, while demonizing those that should be empathized with. This is not worth your time and definitely not worth your money. Even if you have some of either to burn I urge you to find absolutely anything else to spend it on.

There will be a spoiler heavy final thought at the bottom of this review hidden with the spoiler tag.  But for now, here is my spoiler free review.The morally bankrupt â€˜The Suicide of Rachel Fosterâ€™ takes its cues from The Shining and Firewatch for sure.  Two things which will surely switch a lot of people on.  But the game unfortunately fails to deliver and while it hits a few good points there are a string of very bad misses.------ PROS +  graphics.  The Overlook, I mean The Timberline, has some areas of great detail.  The books have blurb on the dust jacket, the walls and staircases look real and the wind whips the trees through frosted windows. Sometimes though, the textures were neglected in other areas resulting in a bit of a clash at points. +  sound.  The sound in this game is on point.  Everything makes the right noise and the hotel has some really well done creepy background noise going on.  The music is great too.  Job well done.+  voices.  Nicole (our protagonist) and Irving (our FEMA agent on the other end of the phone line) are excellently voiced. Canâ€™t fault them at all. +  creepy.  Playing with headphones and walking through the hotel you will hear some sudden and quite loud, unsettling noises.  There are sealed off areas that hold the hotelâ€™s secrets and when found reveal some very good horror elements.  The game sustained this vibe for the most part of the game.  There was always an unnerving tension in me.----- CONS -	the nameâ€™s Bob.  Head bob.  If you insist on putting Bob in your games at least give us the option to get rid of him.  I donâ€™t even get motion sickness but I just canâ€™t stand this being in games.-	confusing map doesnâ€™t really make a lot of sense.  The game might have been going for a  Winchester House [www.mentalfloss.com] kind of feel (which actually would be a great idea for a game) but the awkward map layout paired with the amount or backtracking and U-Turns you will have to make at the start as you get lost in this horribly designed hotel gets old fast.-	story.  There will be spoilers below regarding this just awful wasted chance at a great story.  They had already borrowed a lot from The Shining and I was digging it.  They completely ruined it for me.-	Character: Unlikeable.  Nicole is not a character I could get behind.  She was â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ to people trying to help her, sheâ€™s selfish, sheâ€™s generally very hard to support.  Which would be fine if they developed her character and she went through some arc which was revealed at the end of the game (more about this in the spoilers below) but they donâ€™t. -	somebody save me.  The save system sucks.  You get one save when you finish the chapter.  So if you get lost and canâ€™t figure out where you are going or you just want to go to bed.  Sorry.  You are starting from the beginning of the chapter again.   ----So I find it hard to recommend this game because I just do not agree with the story.  The story ruins the whole game and the fact that the developers wrote this trash and were happy with the script they produced makes me even more upset.  I bought this game mainly because Daedalic were publishing it and I love walking sims. I will be wary of them in the future.  If you want the spoiler version then read onâ€¦ An absolute missed opportunity of a game in so many ways.  The only thing this game manages to hit bang on the money is normalising statutory rape.  I donâ€™t give a damn if the age of consent is 16.  If two teenagers want to bang each othersâ€™ brains out thatâ€™s their business but if one of my friends my age comes sniffing around my 16 year old daughter and gets her pregnant then he will get his skull caved in with a hockey stick.  I felt very left of centre finishing this game.  And I don't usually mind that. I enjoy having my thoughts and feelings challenged but not this time.  I thought I was in for a walking sim along the lines of The Shining.  Snowed in, in a creepy hotel with crazy carpeting, strange sounds, a believable ghost storyâ€¦hell, you even get locked in a pantry for a while.  But no, the game starts out going for the narrative heavy Edith Finch/Firewatch kind of walking sim but then pivots to ghost hunting, which I was totally okay with.  There is a great scene in a room that had a team of ghost hunters staying in for the night.  But in the end the character we play doesnâ€™t see the problem with her father cheating on her mother with a schoolkid who he was tutoring.  She defends her fatherâ€™s crime of â€œloving someoneâ€ right to the end.  The developers had a chance to really take an in depth look at this taboo subject but itâ€™s almost an afterthought.  Like, yeah he got Rachel pregnant, but hey, kids, what ya gonna do?  The game was even trying to make me feel sorry for him and Nicoleâ€™s reluctance to ever blame her father for anything just felt weird to me.  How can you make a game where you expect me to play a game that supports a child molester?  Letâ€™s not even get into the fact that in the very late game in their â€˜love denâ€™ in the attic there are sketches of a scantily clad 16 year old lying around for you to have a look at.  If this isnâ€™t bad enough, Irving, who turns out to be Rachelâ€™s brother ended up being Nicoleâ€™s fatherâ€™s sidekick after Rachelâ€™s death as they hunt for her ghost.  WHAT?  Oh but its ok because it was the mother that killed Rachel and made it look like a suicide.  Sheâ€™s the bad one.  Daddy Polanski over here gets a free pass though.  Come onâ€¦.    Edit: I wrote this as a response to some of the comments below but I felt that they could add some context to the review as well. These responses that protest that 16 years old is only a DEFCON level 5 of paedophilia or that a 16 year old is an adult and anyone who thinks otherwise is an out of touch boomer are laughable and not worth even engaging in so I wonâ€™t.  Armchair Wikipedia psychologists aside, what I do want to do here is continue to clarify my review.  The writing in this game is trash-tier garbage.My problem is not that a 50 year old is molesting a 16 year old schoolkid.  It is that the game doesnâ€™t challenge me in any way.  The characters (all of them) in the game are utterly irredeemable.  I can watch Cronenbergâ€™s Crash with disgust, I can read the cycle of abuse and that Charlieâ€™s aunt molested him in Perks of Being a Wallflower, I can play Silent Hill 2 and grapple with the r.ape and abuse of Angela and I can sit through the violence and horror of Blood Meridian at the cheapness of life.  These things challenge me and at the end of the day have meaning and resolution.  TSORF has no great revelation, no great resolution, no great message, no challenge whatsoever.  All it has is a poor script, which is voiced excellently in a very pretty setting.  The story has been given no thought and just keeps doubling down on its creep factor.  The childâ€™s dungeon shrine is the stuff of horror games and movies but here it misses its mark.  It is not used to challenge the gamer at all.  Bad writing and bad execution.  Then the attic love nest, Flowers in the Attic indeed.  Again...nothing.  Just the normalization of statutory r.ape.The game interested a lot of people because it has a high production value, it is a walking sim which a lot of people enjoy and canâ€™t get enough of and it was produced by Daedalic.  The game succeeds as a walking sim but Daedalic have failed greatly here to produce a work of merit which takes a taboo subject and explores it.  In fact it does the opposite.  It says everything is A-OK and just leaves it at that and expects you to be on board with that.  No father or mother reading this review in their right mind would see no problem in their married friend, with 40 years on their daughter, screwing her in the attic.  The problem is, the game thinks this is completely fine.

A classic walking simulator with a horror-like atmosphere that starts strong but eventually crumbles under its own weight.The best feature of this game is the location: the Timberline Hotel is absolutely gorgeous and well designed. It almost feels like the player walks the halls of a real location. Graphics are overall beautiful, although there are a few low-quality textures here and there.Sound design is fantastic: the ambient sounds fit the location and the setting, the floor creaks, crawlspace walls crumble, the wind howls, and so on. If you play the game with headphones on you can completely immerse yourself in the gameplay.Voice acting is great, the actors really bring the two main characters of the game to life.The game establishes a creepy ambience right from the start and manages to uphold it until the very end, keeping the player in an almost constant unnerving tension - without using cheap tricks.Unfortunately, as the story progresses, the weak points of the game start to come out.After the first hour, it becomes obvious that there is absolutely no point in exploring since nothing can be discovered or learned in addition to what the scripted story gives you. You can inspect several items but they provide no new information making this activity useless. There are certain items that are clearly visible or even highlighted but cannot be interacted with until the plot needs them.The hotel building turns out to be underutilized: a three-story building where most of the rooms are inaccessible and the player is confined into the hallways, the stairway, the first floor, and the basement. Locations that are not included in the plot can be completely avoided which is a shame since they are so well-designed.Another weakness is the overuse of the "mobile phone": the verbal communication between the two main characters becomes effusive which not only slows down progression (making the player wait until the conversation is done) but it even goes to the detriment of visual communication. Games, especially walking simulators, should show, not tell.However, most devastating was the story and the character development. The plot starts OK and manages to keep the player captivated. There are subtle signs that things are not as they seem (some not so subtle, like Miss Flattery), strange things start to happen but then the whole story gradually becomes weird. Somehow, nobody wants to address the illicit relationship of Nicole's father and Rachel and the game even wants to justify it as pure love.None of the characters are likeable: the only exception is Rachel but she is basically reduced to a plot device.The player character, Nicole, changes her personality twice without any explanation - this is partially caused by the episodic nature of the plot. She also acts dumb: for example, there is a plot item on top of a note saying "breadcrumb" yet she does not seem to understand what that means.The father is presented as a misjudged victim instead of a manipulative person who influenced not one but two minors. His obsession is culminated in the act of using his last message to his own daughter to lament about Rachel. The fact that the mother is blamed for everything and the father is acquitted is hard to understand.The ending feels unfounded and forced. The climax and the final scene is separated by a fade-to-black - how and why Nicole gets into that situation remains unexplained.

The best thing about this game was the hotel itself. it was beautiful. The worst thing was the way they talked about the "relationship" between Rachel and the father. It was gross. I wouldnt describe a 16 yr old and an old man who was her mentor as a "love affair". Some weird â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥.

Started this game thinking it'll be a scary walking simulator and psychological horror/depressive themes - I wasn't disappointed! I was super anxious about jump scares but there are none except for shutting doors sometimes. Also:  I think a manequin moved at one point but I may've imagined that. The voice acting is phenomenal, Kosha Engler and Christopher Ragland were CARRYING this game on their shoulders. First problem with the game: optimization. I played on medium with no motion blur and while the game is, indeed, stunning, the audio was constantly cutting off. Whenever The characters were  speaking, I had to stop moving, otherwise the audio would cut or the characters would talk over one another :l. It wasn't game breaking but definitely immersion breakingNow...... The story. Ohhh The story. As many have already said, it's the story/ending that ruin this game's entire potential. If you are looking for a scary walking sim with no jumpscares and good story... you're wrong. Once I finished the game, my first reaction was: What a complete  waste of time. And I geniuely enjoyed the first ~4h of the game. I absolutely loved it.  I didn't expect to write this as a Not Recomended review.Spoilerless conclusion: Story starts out really nice, characters are amazing, but as the story progresses halfway through, certain topics are handled very badly, which can break your immersion and even leave a bad taste in your mouth. Spoilers and spoilery conclusion concerning the story and a rant: Let's start of with the main problem in this whole story: We are a woman, whose 49 year old father slept with a dyslexic 16 year old. The age is apparently never the problem, the game is keep talking about LOVE and how great love is and that people (Nicole's mum) were at fault that their LOVE didn't work out. I was cringing the entire time, especially since Nicole didn't once call BS at that. I get her father may have been a pedo who was  justifying his own actions and called his affair with a child "Love" but I was super surprised Nicole didn't once disregard it. Then Irving, his sudden change of character... okay, a cheap twist, I can go with it, but him being completely ON BOARD with the relationship?? Calling it love??? It's not love, it's grooming, absolutely disgusting. I was SURE he would make Leonard responsible for her  death, saying if he hadn't groomed her, none of this would've happened!!! Also what was the whole flirting about if he turns out to be the "antagonist" and is going to commit suicide in the end anyway? At least let us have a chance to save him if we're being friendly to him? That was totally pointless. I hated that we couldn't save him. I completely understood that he was bitter and blamed everything on Nicole, but he was just as shocked and broken. He was redeemable, there should've been an option to save him and be there for him. The ghost hunters plot was... eh, I guess? It was there. I'm happy they didnt end up actually going further with it. It was very clear from the start that Rachel didn't kill herself and it was a set up. My money was on the father or the priest (Rachel's father), the mother doing it was a nice twist. But... God it was handled so wrong. Not ONCE is the father, the child molesting tutor the problem No, he is seen as a â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ SAVIOUR! Apparently the ~jealous wife~ is the only issue here!! That was absolutely disgusting, made me sick to the stomach to call child abuse "love" and it not being called out for what it is! Instead, the only papers that call the father out are lablled as "slander". I get that Irving wants closure, but why praising Leonard? Why is Nicole still referring to him as "daddy" and being affectionate? Her change in character is just strange, it felt like the more she learned about her father, the more she missed him?? I understand she may feel guilty because of Rachel and not being able to help her.. But to ignore everything her father did (grooming/molesting/impregnating a child, cheating on his wife with said child, having a psychopathic shrine for that child nearly underneath the church) and then still call him "daddy" and reminisce? And what's up with the option of Nicole committing suicide in the end?? It makes absolutely no sense. And if she doesn't die, she sounds like a psychopath holding those retrainers and speaking to her "parents" about restoring the hotel... as if she had lost it.If you want to give us an angsty, depressive ending then have Nicole sit against the wall, with the mobile on her ear trying to reach Irving while crying. The actress would've killed it. Or maybe the other way around of Irving trying the suffocating/ed Nicole in the car after all? Or just give us a good ending of her convincing Irving not to do it and them having their â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ date. They deserve to feel loved because that's what they were missing for over 10 years. He was living isolated in a dark room and she was bitter and didn't rely or trust anyone until he came along. He sounded like he genuiely liked her and she even started liking him too. They were each other's light, almost. Conclusion: â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ ending, couldn't save Irving who I really liked, the pedophile is praised for banging a dyslexic child, the only evil here is apparently the mother.

UPDATED REVIEW**Very good game Darkest dungeon alike but without the grinding mechanics, just fights and a bit of your cementery management, that makes it a much faster game.They are increasing and improving the mechanics of the game each dlc/patch. The last DLC was a huge step in the right direction, adding enemies and randomizing bosses, and at the same time they added more items and minions. These changes give more replayability to the game, that is in my opinion what a roguelike should always focus on.It only lacks mod support to be a legendary game that would last many years being played. Maybe in the future they will add that too.

Alright we already know this game is a lot like Darkest Dungeon on a core level. What you're probably asking yourself is "what can I do in this that I can't in Darkest Dungeon already?", so I'll summarize it for you.-Play as the Darkest Dungeon itself with your goal being to piss on the Hamlet instead of trying to rebuild it.-Have the stress system on your side where the enemy is the one trying to roll against afflictions at 100 stress and dying to heart attacks instead of you (and yes, stress builds are a thing and are perfectly viable depending on the enemy).-Assume direct control in combat with a mana system that lets you personally blast the enemy with cheap magic spells from the safety of your home. (There's even a wine skeleton spell for stressing everyone on the enemy team)-Manage the health of your monsters because they don't heal between fights by either sending them to the morgue for their version of a relaxing vacation, or performing dark alchemy by taking whatever organs, bones, or trash you have laying around your house and distilling them into funny zombie beer.-Control an army of undead who are both willing to play as a team and step right the hell over one another in a desperate power-struggle for your affection, such as the ghoul who can cannibalize her own team for health, or the Bone Golem who is willing to explode and die for your sins at a moments notice.-Equip items like burning blood and cannibals jaw to a Lich to create a miniboss that will have the enemy screaming in eldritch horror as they are single handedly wiped out by a funny floating skeleton who gets absurd stat bonuses for being alone on the field and whenever an ally dies.-Cry when your favorite monster gets nuked because there's no death's door mechanic, only suffering, but sigh in relief as you're able to get a new one up and running so long as you have an appropriately leveled brain you can place into it.-The zombie has a gun.If any of that sounds interesting, then you should give this game a whirl. It's really good. Flawed in some aspects, like enemy variety is kinda shallow and there's currently no workshop, but I'd say it's still a really fun experience.

It would be easy to write off Iratus as a Darkest Dungeon clone. In many ways it is. a hand drawn dungeon crawler using a customized party of 4 with permadeath and a haunting aesthetic.But in many ways I prefer it to Darkest Dungeon. First, it eliminates the need to grind as there are a fixed number of encounters in the game. Second, it offers multiple difficulty levels to ease people into what can be a very difficult game. Third, characters can be customized in both ability customization and stat distribution. The quirky "quirks" system is gone from Iratus. Lastly, instead of being victims of insanity, you can inflict psychic damage on your foes.The story, art direction, and voice acting are probably better in Darkest Dungeon, but these are all still good here. Most importantly, there's plenty of gameplay depth in customizing your minions, the artifacts they equip, the spells you take into battle, and global artifacts you can use. The DLC is also a great purchase.I liked Darkest Dungeon, but this is a pretty damn good clone.

Being a massive fan of Darkest Dungeon, I actually avoided this game for a while. Naturally thinking this was just some cheap clone of sorts, or just not worth my time. I am glad to report I was extremely incorrect, and I owe Irratus a sincere apology.Its fantastic. I had an absolute blast, beginning to end and I'll probably play it at least another time. I love this game, between its themes, its gameplay, and its maybe slightly cheesy but highly enjoyable story.Lets not beat around the bush: the crux of this game is that it's an inversion of Darkest dungeon's paradigm. Instead of being heros desperately battling eldritch horrors, trying to stay both alive and sane, you *are* the horror. The minions at your disposal are extremely well designed, interesting, and varied to a pretty shocking degree. None of them copy roles from DD either, which surprised me as I expected at least some retreaded ground, but in some ways Iratus may some minions even more interesting than DD. A wide variety of fantasy monster tropes, all with unique strengths and weaknesses that are incredibly fun to exploit. Lots of tearing flesh, consuming souls and damning the indignant mortals with stacks and stacks of curses. Break their spirits and send them running, or break their bodies and send them into your hellish ranks. Its great.The biggest difference from DD that's immediately noticeable is the difficulty curve, and if you liked DD but struggled to actually beat it, Iratus is definitely for you. That's not to say its easy, it just gives you way more time to find your footing than DD does. You can curbstomp the first couple floors with ease, building up minions, learning what works and what doesnt *before* the game smacks you with the really hard stuff. And for veterans, dont worry. This game has serious teeth towards the endgame.While likely not the draw, I also quite enjoyed the story. Playing as this intensely powerful necromancer breaking free is an awesome gothic power fantasy, and it really nails the feel of you being the villain in someone else's story. Iratus is charming and maniacal, the heros appropriately stuffy and dour as to make crushing them devilishly fun. It has a little twist I also enjoy, but I shan't spoil it.If you like the genre, Iratus is well worth the chance. Its really something fun and special, and I'm very excited for any potential future content or sequel.PS. If its on sale, go ahead and grab the DLC too. Its just even more content, and well worth it.

It's like Darkest Dungeon In about 2 ways. The combat and the team building.That's about where the similarities end.Iratus is much more winnable. Gone is the brutally tedious resource management, where you never have enough gold, ever. Iratus makes it so with smart choices, you're slowly progressing, and you feel it.Now you're the one causing stress, making enemies attack eachother, become weaker or flee due to insanity. No more burning gold on de-stressing.Team building is just as important, with many synergies to exploit. No more random caravan, build your damn army from parts you get from killing enemies. Unlock new minions by completing clear 'challanges'.Are you later into the game and you have a new unit you want to make, but you know it will be level 1? Easy fix, jam a high level brain, that you can find by killing enemies, into your new minion and they'll just be that level now.Iratus presents a challenge that you can overcome. It's not easy, but it's not ball-wrenchingly difficult either.

Iratus is just difficult enough to scratch my masochistic itch, and just forgiving enough to stop me from throwing my computer out the window. This is a great game that is worth playing if you love rogue strategies. It leans heavily on Darkest Dungeons, but brings enough new ideas to make giving it a positive review an easy choice. That being said the game is not without its flaws. The GoodThere is plenty to like about Iratus, Lord of the Dead. For starters, it has monster levels, hero levels, artifacts, alchemy, monster parts, monster trinkets and a ton more ways to plan your strategy. I won't explain all the categories, but safe to say, there is always room for improvement on your teams. And no one team is perfect for every scenario. Creativity is rewarded and the different areas to improve on are well explained in the game.The biggest difference form darkest dungeon, your monsters (heroes) will die. It's build into the game to be able to replenish you ranks. Sometimes you will get unlucky, and the RNG won't go your way. You will think you have the perfect team, but then you will lose them in a bad beat. But the game is designed for you to bounce back, even on harder difficulties. Not only is this a difficult thing to accomplish, it's thematically accurate because you're a necromancer that does not care about your minions (you say it a lot throughout the game). Points for originality.  Smooth, pretty, reactive, with great sound effects. Do I need to say more? They get the parts you need to get right, right.The BadYou have to beat every difficulty in ascending order. In order to play the hardest difficulty, you have to beat the equivalent of easy, medium, and hard, first. If you want that juicy achiv, you will have to beat the game no less than four times. Why does the game limit me? Let me play on whatever damn difficulty I want. If I don't like it than I can always go easier. I always hate this feature when games makes the decision for you. Not the longest game in the world. The game only has five levels and can be beat in a pretty short amount of time (15 hours or so.) I would hate to think that is why they make you beat the game three times before you can even try the hardest difficulty. That is lazy, busy work. Not too much of a story line either. But that can be forgiven because the genre does not call for an in-depth story line. It just would have been nice to have a few more cut scenes and another writer on the project. I played it and I enjoyed trying to master it. I will definitely play any DLCs. Darkest Dungeons is the crown jewel of the genre but Iratus is not far behind. Think Pippin just barely trailing Jordan, but still just as vital to the team. Iratus does a lot for the genre as a whole and is pushing it into new and interesting directions.
Product refunded

Game is abandoned in a completely unfinished state.The game launched with heaps of potential but a deluge of issues, from broken pathfinding to single digit performance in the late game despite being at best comparable to Warcraft 3 or Dawn of War 1 technically. The Devs acknowledged these issues day 1 and promised these issues had already been fixed or were in the process of being fixed. The patch never came.The Devs went completely silent over the launch window, killing whatever little community existed. The next thing the Devs announced was that the game was cancelled due to a lack of long term interest (because they never even bothered to make the game playable despite promissing to have all the fixes ready).Only a partial campaign exists, complete with an utterly nonsensical story and completely unfinished/unplayable levels that are near impossible without repeated playthroughs thanks to the lack of even a basic save feature.Absolute garbage dev/publisher, don't even consider supporting them.

The good: Being a warcraft 3 clone isn't necessarily bad. Although the similarities are just too many, you can ignore them and enjoy the graphics and the good attempt at creating the heroes and the abilities as well as the good voice acting. The price is also alright.The bad: Balancing is an issue. You will lose battles on casual difficulty and there is no save game. You could call it a progressive idea for a RTS if it wasn't for the pathfinding.The ugly: Pathfidning is a disaster. It is very rare that your units will go the way you want them to and very frequent that they will get stuck somewhere that they can never leave. With no hope of ever escaping, adding to your pop limit and with no save game, you have to replay the whole mission... Sad times indeed.The verdict: Although the game is decent in some aspects, pathfinding is too horrible to overlook. A failed attempt at a RTS: 3/10

I would recommend this game if you can grab it for $5 as I did, it was a nice time sink and its pretty fun as is.A couple things I would note before buying.Pros:Love the approach on the art style.Good SoundtrackGood Campaign Story, what's there of it.Likeable "Hero Characters"Fun Gameplay, enough for me to finish the Campaign on Hard.Charming in a rough around the edges and cracked through the center kind of wayCons:AI has absolutely terrible pathfinding as is, utterly terrible.There are some maps and levels that pathfinding does not exist at all, some parts of the maps are just not traverse-able, units making obnoxious map wide loop arounds.Units and Resources get stuck in cliffs, trees, underground and you are unable to move them afterwards, effectively needing to kill them and just re-train.Game has issues selecting units in a rapid manner and will not always pick up your actions, an extension of this state is also the game runs extremely rough, even on Ultra High-End Systems.  During certain levels and skirmishes, when there was no more than 30-40 units on the field and not a lot of effects, I would see FPS drops down to 10-15 from 165 almost out of nowhere.  This effect happens no matter the graphics settings.Quick System Info:Ryzen 3900X - Liquid CooledMSI RTX 2080TI - Liquid Cooled32GB G.SKILL RamGen 4 Sabrent NVME SSD 2TB
It's like Warcraft 3 but with cool additional features like only one hero, no items, and the worst pathfinding I've ever seen in an RTS.

While hunting down a swarm of Mudraptors, we got blindsided by several Hammerheads from the rear. What followed was a desperate scramble for pressure suits as our sub quickly flooded and several Mudraptors found their way inside. Our security and medical officers fought hand to hand with the raptors, holding them back while the rest of us manned the guns as we fell into the abyss. After a tense few minutes all the monsters were slain, and we began to repair the ship. Just as we began to stabilize however, we were slammed into again, this time by an abyss creature larger than our vessel. We sank down to the sea floor, battling the monster all the way. I swam back and forth through the wreck, desperately repairing the reactor and junction boxes to keep the coil-guns online as our systems took constant water damage. We ran out of ammunition for the sub and resorted to firing with assault rifles and handguns, using the carcass of our own vessel as cover. Down to our last mags, our captain landed a shot with his revolver that finally felled the beast. After a total of nearly 20 minutes of pure chaos, our submarine began to pump out water, and we limped our way back to port. Somehow, through all of it, none of us perished.The very next mission I got crushed by a random piece of falling ice and died instantly. 10/10 game

I was a doctor named Dr. Iam Realdoktor (its european) just trying to save my patients (valuable organs). That was until someone attempted to poison me with denatured alcohol. I Injected myself with so many stimulants and detoxers that I was a god. He then tried to fight a god, and was smited by my double barrel which sent them flying across the sub right into the arms of security. I, being a real and good doctor that has a degree in doctoring attempted to save the pathetic life of this mere mortal. I bandaged him up just enough to prevent him from bleeding out. But mistakes happen in the depths, I mixed up my bloodpack with radiotoxin ( a common doctoring mistake), could have been some of the leftover alcohol. His body was melting, even if I would have administered pain killers his body probably wouldnt have helped......probably.  I kept him alive long enough to make sure he felt everything. When he begged me to let him die, I said of course. So I dragged his flesh jello-ed future corpse down into the subs airlock, him screaming with what little air he could muster the entire way. Then ejected him out into the depths and watched as the sheer pressure just created a cloud of red fluid. The notes I have on the event where utterly fascinating.I am a real doctor. This is just my first impression of the first game I played, here's all the crazy â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ that happened:I spawn into my first sub as a medic, greeted by the captain who was dressed as a clown and playing a harmonica in my face (Immediately, what the â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥?).I went into the medical bay where there was already 2 dead people and another unconscious.At the same time, I could hear screaming of an engineer and a couple security guys saying "THEY GOT IN, THEY GOT IN!"I grabbed medical supplies and tried my best to resuscitate the unconscious guy in the medbay using what I learned in the tutorial which absolutely did not prepare me for the chaos and â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ that was going on.The guy dies, I had literally no idea what I was doing.I grab his crowbar and sprint into the captains quarters where my superior officer, the clown, was using a shotty to hold off an unbelievable number of monsters. I help him by Morgan Freemaning the â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ out of their skulls.We're both dying, the clown goes unconscious, I manage to save myself from the same fate. I perform CPR on the clown and bring him back to life.We both limp below deck where only the engineer is left, he somehow killed them all and was repairing the breaches.The clown gets on the hull guns, his happy facepaint hiding his terrified tears.I help the engineer repair the ship. Whilst we are repairing the electrics, he is shocked and goes into cardiac arrest. I perform CPR and somehow bring him back from joining the rest of the crew in the forever sleep.We get the ship powered again, I take over the guns from the clown, he climbs the ladder back up to his alien-corpse-ridden quarters and directs us towards the closest docking station.With me shooting down the horde, the engineering performing repairs (still screaming btw), and the clown steering us home, we somehow manage to achieve our goal.That was an absolute baptism by fire. I've not had that much fun in a game in years. What an awesome â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ game Barotrauma is. I can't wait to do it all again tomorrow. 10/10.

JOGO: The Lord of the Rings: Gollum
COMENTARIO: Original ReviewI am honestly shocked at the absolute gall of Nacon to charge $50 for a game of such poor quality. This is an obviously amateur product across every dimension, riddled with so many technical and creative design flaws that the AAA-tier asking price beggars belief. The game looks, sounds, and handles like a student project demonstrating their first legitimate wrangling of Unreal Engine. Games of this calibre are typically free on Steam, which feels like the only appropriate price point for this product.I'll update this review when I've finished, though I expect my regard for the game will only grow all the more scathing for each passing hour. I leave this thumbs-down in the meantime, in the hopes that it may help ward off prospective buyers.Post-Completion UpdateI guess I should at least list a few of the game's positive points, out of a bounty of good faith. The Gollum video game has some nice environment art, a few good pieces of music, and one Orc voice actor who really killed it with his lines.Everything else about this game is, unfortunately, irredeemably bad. Awful character models, cumbersome camera movement, jerky animations, low-quality textures, totally borked occlusion silhouettes...from minute one, Gollum gives off a pretty rough vibe, very amateur, very unpolished. And that would be entirely fine, if the game didn't cost $50.Everything about Gollum feels cheap, from its minimal storybook-style cutscenes, to the way that you ragdoll five feet into a fatal fall and just statically descend in a straight line while lying down as if you'd landed on an invisible floor, to the way that jumping over certain pieces of furniture results in your character awkwardly floating over them in a suspended falling animation. The game's text is rife with typos and grammatical errors, mixed tenses, and informal or contemporary language jarringly inserted into in-universe lore entries and recaps.Facial animations are stiff and abruptly revert to neutral positions when a line of dialogue ends. plenty of character actions and game events have no accompanying SFX. the poorly implemented motion blur can't be disabled (unless they've since patched this). low draw distance, massive pop-in, constant frame hitches, the list of technical problems goes on and on and on.You are presented with all of these problems before you even begin to play the game, a fresh nightmare unto itself. Gollum handles poorly in all regards: jumps will often careen out of control, there is minimal to no mid-air course correction, the pre-pathed climbing controls are abysmal, and even your default movement speed is pitifully slow. If you jump while climbing a ladder and nearing the top, Gollum will spring up wildly into the air in a directly vertical line, and then fall straight back down onto the ladder. It's difficult to articulate how completely bizarre this looks and feels in context.This is a stealth game which places a single viable tool into your toolkit: throwing rocks to distract guards. It is a platformer in which your stamina bar runs out in about a second and a half, and returns at an excruciating rate. Certain paths for jumps seem to have been designated as the "correct" path, and the trajectory of any adjacent jump will crazily whiplash to adhere to them. This game's resolute eschewals of the design sensibilities dutifully accrued across three decades of industry exploration in 3D platforming are as ruinous as they are grimly hilarious.I want to return for a moment to the game's technical woes, because they are both innumerable and worthy of contemplation.- Around a third of the lines in the game had no accompanying lip-sync animations during my playthrough- Objective markers jittered wildly when moved to the screen border- Lighting effects often displayed fully through opaque barriers- Some in-game cutscene camera angles qwre bugged, and entire scenes were blocked by a T-posing NPC or piece of the environment- SFX or voice lines that were playing prior to a death often persisted through to my next spawn- The faces on certain Elf NPCs were severely distorted during speech, with eyebrows and eyelids grotesquely pulling back inside the skull of the character- Several dialogue trees incorrectly displayed the same prompt for every option on screen- Multiple dialogue options enacted nothing when selected. Gollum simply stared blankly at the camera for 10-15 seconds, and then the scene continued- During many parts of the game, skipping dialogue lines did not cut off the previous line - it simply continued to play overtop of the next line of dialogue. This effect could be compounded ad nauseam to experience true madness- I encountered many cutscenes where the currently speaking NPC de-rendered, existing only as a disembodied voice- Several platforms in the Riddlemaster's quarters don't seem to have been properly engineered. You're clearly supposed to jump off of these platforms to go higher, but only a very small subarea of each platform can be jumped from. The jump button does nothing when you are standing anywhere else on the platform- I encountered several instances where my character became stuck inside the geometry of underwater obstacles, soft-locking me and forcing a restart- On more than one occasion, NPCs got stuck bumping into each other on the way out of my prison cell, and became unable to proceed through the doorway. This also trapped me in the cell, forcing a restartDo not think this scouring of the game's many failures will be limited to the technical side of things. The issues I've listed above, and even my more general complaints about the game's overall "cheap" feel, could theoretically be addressed by arduous post-launch support. But The Lord of the Rings: Gollum is rotten to its very bones, for many more reasons than I've enumerated above. Paywalled emotes in a single-player title are already enough to make my skin crawl, but locking a Sindarin voice pack behind Day 1 DLC strikes me as much worse - especially because, as I understand, this DLC barely adds more than a handful of lines. This is content that was finished at launch, and should have been included for the base price.Still more issues gnaw at this corpse of a game. The first three chapters could have been an intro cutscene or text summary. you do nothing but rote chores, barely advancing any existing plotlines. Gollum also features an underbaked "companion" system during certain levels, and it is always to the player's detriment. A mid-game chase sequence with a large monster is implemented as a bottom-of-the-barrel quality Banjo Kazooie segment that goes on for way too long and features a maddeningly short music sample on loop - and then, after a short platforming section, you go through the exact same ordeal again.Most of the marketing material for this game advertised it as an adventure that spans the breadth of Middle Earth, starring Gollum and a mysterious Elf companion. But the game is 10 chapters long, and you don't really leave Mordor until Chapter 7.Gollum bears all the pockmarks of a project that was clearly developed under extreme duress, and I feel great sympathy for the dev team at Daedalic. Any ridicule they have been targeted with is severely misdirected.Management and publishing, on the other hand, were out of their minds to release this game - and it's a shame, because I am given to understand that Daedalic has previously held a reasonably good reputation for their point-and-click adventure games. And now, as a result of this wild, reckless negligence, their development wing has been shut down entirely, and talented developers have lost their jobs.I would end this review by saying "Gollum is a terrible video game," but that is inaccurate - because The Lord of the Rings: Gollum is not a video game. It is a monument to the sins of man.

JOGO: The Lord of the Rings: Gollum
COMENTARIO: Unlike most reviews i have actually played it to the end, so buckle up and let me tell you about my suffering.When i heard that Daedalic got the rights to LOTR i was so excited. For i have played a number of their Point and Click adventures and they are master storytellers. And they decided to tell the story of the most tragic character (Apart from HÃºrin and his family) in the entire Legendarium.So what in IlÃºvatar's name happened!?First of the game runs at least for me but i see a lot of people having huge performance issues. But this cannot redeem the awful controls and platforming. Movement is so stiff and prepare to die a lot from falling. I also encountered quite a number of bugs like getting stuck on terrain, not willing to grab ledges and most hilarious and frustrating of all A wheel that i was supposed to jump on totally defining the laws of physics and just disappearing into the wall.But Daedalic are great at making stories i think back at Chains of Satinav and Memoria so i pushed forward. But more than half of the game is spend in the dungeons Barad-DÃ»r bearly moving the plot onward. Characters are gone as soon as they appear and have no depth to them. It teases you and when it starts getting interesting it's over. For example there is an old man in your cell and you discover he was a Haradrim king and thats it you will never see him again. And you spend much of your time doing just boring tasks for your masters. The reason for my focus on this part is that we already have a game that did this so much better. In The Lord of the Rings Online if you make a Stout-Axe character you start in thralldom in the Dark Tower together with your fellow clan members You get a short idea how your life goes and do mundane tasks until word gets out that a certain prisoner of the dark lord is set to be released, a riot breaks out and you escape. All this takes about 15-20 Min if you do not skip the dialogue But here it is the majority of the game. And ones you get out of Mordor you skip right to you imprisoned in Mirkwood. (No you do not get to see Aragorn hunt you) And for some reason the Elves are very cold and mean against you. This is so strange as in fact in the book the elves took pity on Gollum. There is a lot to say about the bafeling story decisions but this review would be an novel in itself.The last time I was so disappointed with a game was Stronghold 3 many years ago and this might be the worst game of the year. I just wish that Daedalic would have played it simple for their first venture into my favorite fantasy universe and made a Point and Click of The Hobbit
